reviewText: I've played the tabletop version of this, as well as Hordes. In my opinion, the game is heading in a good direction, trying to keep the tabletop experience as realistic as possible. Gameplay, I'd give a 9/10. Now, for the bad stuff. The game is hardly optimized, to the point of averaging ~12fps. While I figured there was a workaround, judging from the forums, this is not the case. The other negative is that they are trying to monetize their units in a simlar manner to the tabletop version. DLC consists of a couple units here and there, or sole units. This has been done to the point where the DLC outcosts the base game. Warhammer 40k seems to have found a good route, where each expansion has the full set of units available, without microtransactions. Customization is also non-existent as of yet, and you are pretty much stuck with the base schemes for each unit. If they want to release Hordes, they've got a long way to go.

reviewText:
The controls are lackluster at best.

I would not recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText:
Warmachine Tactics has a lot going for it, and a lot holding it back.

First, the negative: production values are inconsistent. A lot of still portraits, and in many cases, still models in cutscenes whose mouth's don't move while they talk. Various UI glitches that may force you to skip unit activations. Scripted events throughout the campaign make it less about tactics, and more about just getting through the mission. No saving mid-level (this means if you don't have at least an hour or so each mission, you are likely to lose a lot of progress if you have to stop playing).

Despite all of that, there are a lot of good things about Warmachine Tactics. A unique world, setting and units based on the award winning tabletop game: WARMACHINE. The rules and interactions are very deep with many different things to consider throughout a match. There is an unlimited amount of replayability as unit selection and opponent choices make it so no two matches are exactly alike.

If you are willing to look past various annoyances in the production of the game, this title has a lot of excellent tactical wargaming to be had. Anyone who is a fan of grid-based strategy games would be remiss to not give this game a chance.

7/10 Good""

reviewText: Where to begin. Probably with the Kickstarter. The game looked appealing since I play the tabletop game too, so what could be cooler than only getting to play the minis game once or twice a week? Loading up WM: Tactics and playing whenever I want! As a backer I got access to the beta and it was terrible. I ran it on a decent PC but the game was far from optimized, so there were a lot of graphics issues, bugs, etc. Of course I passed no judgment because it was still in beta, but once the game released, very few of those issues disappeared. Now I have a GTX 980, 24 GB RAM, and an i7-4710 but the game is still slow and not very user-friendly. Making selections on the battlefield is difficult, the camera is a pain more often than it's helpful, and the video clips are maybe PS2 quality. The gameplay itself is also very slow, and in the year 2014/2015 I expect a game to be snappy, responsive, and not a steamy pile of trash. Thankfully I got some exclusive" sculpts for the tabletop minis the Kickstarter offered

reviewText:
I only Played the Demo so I don't really know much more about this game. I'll start with some of the things I liked before I get into any of the bad things.

1. The character artwork is great! I saw images of some of the mechs on zbrush central and I started looking for this game right away.

2.Controlling and allocating focus to warjacks was an interesting take on a turn based tactical game like this.

3. I enjoyed the combat and gameplay mechanics. There are many games with these mechanics but the theme was very interesting and exciting for me.

Now I'll go into some of the things that i don't like and again please understand that I only played the demo so my experience is only limited to the 3 missions in the demo.

1. The camera is messed up in the city levels. Every time I would do an attack the camera would start rotating or something around the two characters fighting and the camera would go behind the wall and I would not see the attack or how much damage i did or if i missed.

2. The dialgue was really lame. and to top it off the characters apear to not have any facial rigs. When your in a cutscene with two characters talking the mouths don't move and the camera moves around like its supposed to be a movie or something. I feel they should have gone to text because it threw me off so much that their mouths were not moving. It made it look like some college students last minute project where they had a scene and characters and only had to deal with camera angles. It was so annoying because the camera would even cut to the person talking but all that was happening was the audio but nothing else. I don't know maybe its just a thing that gets on my nerves personally. it doesn't change the outcome of the game in the end so i guess it doesn't matter.

I don't want to put a recommendation out because I haven't played the full game. I will however say that I will not buy this game enless its like 10 dollars. I am interested and I want to play the rest of the game, but based on some of the issues I pointed out i feel it was slapped together at some points and the Camera issues I had in the city level were unbearable. I can't wait till i goes on sale though I really want to see the rest of the Warjacks and character art.

reviewText:
I would recommend this game but with a couple of caveats.

First, it is still getting a lot of bugs out. The game is fun, but can be buggy which takes away a lot from the experience.

Second, this is not Warmachine, but closer to FF Tactics with giant robots. Be prepared for that shock if you were expecting a video game version of the tabletop game.

Third, the game is not worth its full price. The first person game is fairly short (only about 20 mission) and not that inspired so far (I'm about halfway through). The vrs mode is fun but is seem like half of the models are DLC's, which is ridiculous. It feels like the game is trying to penny pinch you and they're doing a good job of it.

If you are interested in this game, wait until there is a sale where you can pick up the game and the DLC's for cheap. Otherwise, its not worth it.

reviewText: I played the demo because of a friend who adores the miniatures game who backed the kickstarter project but didn't have a PC that could run the game. i was kind of on the fence with the other reviews, and I'd also never played the tabletop game before. It's clear the game was SUPER buggy when it first debuted in Early Access and a lot of impulse reviews were responding to that. But I played it anyway, and I was pleasantly suprised. Mind you, there are still some bugs and glitches, but the game is quite fun. Even the voice acting of the campaign characters is suprisingly good, the graphics are great (with a few bugs) and I genuinely had fun playing. It even made me more interested in considering to try out the tabletop game.\n\nIt seems virtually all the negative reviews are either about bugs in the game, or features that were late being delivered. The game seems to be in a pretty good state now and i would reccomend it to anyone looking for a new turn based strategy.

reviewText:
Given the intellectual property of WarMachine, and the vast amount of backstory and creative development this game has, it is an absolute unmitigated let down.

Really they'd be better off letting the community develop a tabletopia mod for the game, or actuallly spend some real money and quality on developing the actual game.

Asthetically, the cut scenes are absolute rubbish, and makes the whole game look as if it was done as a mod project. They would have been better served by going with drawn animations instead of lifeless models that don't really interact with the world.

I don't mind the basics of the turn based combat and there is some fun and strategy to be had, but seriously 20 or 40$ What were they thinking!!!

I got this as a part of a humble bundle deal and at the 2-5$ price point, I think it's a good buy at that price. Anything more and it feels like you're paying for an unfinished product.

And that's before talking about hiding units behind a dlc paywall on top of the base game.

TL:DR
Get it if it's below 5$ and you're a fan of turn based strategy. Don't get it, if it costs more.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you are looking for Warmachine on a PC, know that this is true to the table top game in spirit only. Familiar terms are used, but the game is fundamentally different. You are probably better off just trying to play a game an VASSAL.

If you are looking for turn-based tactical squad combat, you are better off going to play XCOM, this game is poorly optimized, still buggy, and interactions within the game are not well explained.

The price and volume of microtransactions make this game an even worse buy.

I was hopeful for this game, but they strayed too far from the original mechanics, devoted a larger percentage of their time to modeling than they probably should have while under optimizing it, and even cut core concepts.

I have not yet finished the campaign, but so far it feels far too much on rails and forced, what they want to happen will happen regardless of what you try to do to stop it (for story reasons). You get the units they give you, and must play according to what you are given to succeed. They don't explain things you are shown until they feel you need to know, in an early mission you are shown in-game cut-scenes of someone running around at least 2-3 times before they tell you anything about what you are seeing and why it is relevant and potentially too late for you to react. It feels like all of the events that occur are just sitting waiting for a certain turn number before it tells you about it, I was stuck on one mission waiting for a thing to occur because I'd done too well the turns before. The leveling mechanic was a great idea, but also felt very generic. I would have enjoyed earning experience on unit types and being able to customize my forces.

Overall, it feels like this was wasted potential. There was a lot of money and support behind the game, but it feels like the developers went over budget in some early areas and were forced to cut back on concepts that they could no longer afford to develop, specifically lack of units, number of models on the board, size of the board and the campaign. At least I hope that is the case, because if the current product what the developers intended to make, I feel like that was not well communicated during the inital backing process.

reviewText:
This game needs a lot of updates before it's an auto-purchase.
Clumsy and inept AI, Micro-Transactions, 5 total maps for skirmish and mutiplayer after 2 years on Early Access, and game breaking UI and camera visuals all combine to make a game that a lot of people want to be a good game, but just isn't.
The thing that makes this game unplayable for me is the UI and camera - they are obtuse, and very unintuitive - to the point that the camera usually ends up inside a building or a tree and the in-game interface gets in the way of placing and moving units. It's very frustrating when you can't move or place a unit where you want to because the INTERFACE IS IN THE WAY. The interface and terrain are two things that should never get in the way of functionality.
There are die-hard fans that will argue these points to death, but as someone who is not vested in the warmachine universe, I can say that even at the current sale price of $23.99, the game doesn't offer much of a deal.

reviewText:
So, I'll start off with my initial thoughts of the game so far given that the full campaign has only just been released.  *Warning* there will be some slight spoilers.

The good: I've just started to get into the tabletop version of Warmachine and so far what I've played does a good job of keeping to the core mechanics. The graphics are pretty good for a kickstarter game, some CG cutscenes would have been amazing (especially of the duel between Orsus and Sturgis) but that's really asking too much of a limited budget. The gameplay is well done, with actual thought being required so that you don't open yourself up to enemy charges or block your own movement and/or line of sight with an ill-timed activation. That's one aspect of the game I've really enjoyed so far which is good because there are a lot of minor areas that need at least a little improvement.

The bad: The story. The story is almost cringe worthy in its absolute lack of originality and, so far, bad presentation - I mean, another superweapon that could change the course of the war / end the world as we know it plot line? Really? Even the opening scene almost made me facepalm when Jakes stated that I...I killed Commander Stugis". My reaction was no
date: no you didn't. I haven't even played the storyline yet and I know this
recommended: stop being a drama queen. Given the fluff available in the books I was really expecting better
hoursPlayed: even the game characters seem almost caracatures of themselves compared to their presentation in the books. There is one twist that might have been interesting but since anyone with even a nodding acquaintence with the game likely knows what happens to Stugis it's a moot point. I would have liked something more along the lines of the old Dark Omen game where your actions and decisions decided how the story progressed and what units were available.\nThe voice acting isn't bad

reviewText:
As an original Kickstarter backer of this game, it pains me to say how disappointed I am with its execution.  I am not very familiar with the setting beyond hearing the name a few times in tabletop circles, but the story and world shown is execellent.  The graphics are also great for a genre where they are usually an afterthought.  I only wish the gameplay itself seemed like less of an afterthought.

I have to wonder how much experience the gameplay and UI designers have with making games.  You have to manually select each unit before giving them orders instead of auto-selecting the next unit in the list.  There is also no easy way to move the camera so you can actually tell where you're moving.  While I enjoy seeing the action from almost any angle, can we include a consistent way to get an overhead view next time?  And the unit actions themselves can be confusing to navigate and are (again) inconsistent in how they are executed.  Sometimes you click a circle in the unit menu and other times you click on an enemy unit itself.  These are all pretty basic mistakes that should have been caught early on and make the game feel incomplete.

There's a great game buried in here somewhere, but it's hidden behind the terrible controls and clunky camera.

reviewText:
Review based on demo.

Nice graphics, decent concept, pretty interesting game mechanics. Everything is fine and dandy IN THEORY -- until you actually try and play the game.

I would probably enjoy this game if it weren't for the UTTERLY HORRIBLE user interface. This is much worse than XCOM's designed for consoles ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t UI. It never does what you expect it to, and relies on some antediluvian interface design concepts like having large number of buttons on the screen you need to press to do anything. I can't even select unit, de-select it to select another and then re-select it again, as it somehows expects that I'm done with him or something. Really?! Something wrong with just using a minimized mouse-driven UI with context-sensitive actions, maybe context-sensitive menus, simple action point system that stops predicting what the player is trying to do, like when he's done with a unit, whom to attack and so on, and just let the player do anything he wants with minimum effort. Too much?

If you're a game designer or want to be one, please do play this game and take notes on how to NOT design your UI and inputs.

+ I like the free camera, once you toggle it on (kind of confusing to mention those free camera controls in tutorial since it's by default toggled off). Too many games restrict me to their idea of ideal camera angle, which is usually wrong.

reviewText:
Oh, I SO want to like this game. The characters are fine, the setting awesome, but there are just Too many noob mistakes and game breaking bugs to recommend it to anyone but the most avid fan of the Warmachine miniatures game.
Much of the time it feels like you're trying to force the game to behave more than thinking tactically. This is due to a series of major annoyances:
- The 3d engine cannot seem to understand which square you're pointing at, making you constantly 'misclick' and have your troops move to a wrong square, which can cost you the game if someone you need buys it to a free strike
- Free strikes, while we're on it, do not seem to follow the same rules for the player and the ai.
- When moving, the trooper will often turn to a random facing after finishing the move, which looks hilarious at first - the tropper dashes over barrels and walls, then turns around as if pleased with his little hurdles run, but is soon annoying as hell when you have to spend time turning all your troopers back to face the enemy after moving.
- The game rules are explained only in a rudimentory sense, making it near impossible for a person who hasn't played the miniatures game to understand, and is then changed in arbitrary ways. Since when does a Bastion have a charge move longer than the range of a Trencher's rifle? Why no hit locations, systems to disable on jacks? And infantry have Lots of boxes, while jacks have not been significantly boosted.
- Line of sight does not take object height into account; a jack cannot shoot over the heads of infantry. And it seems that if any los possible crosses a square with a friendly trooper, there's no los.
- Scenarios feel forced; there seems to be little to no room to actually Play here; you pretty much have to solve the problem the developers want you to, or fail, to the point where overwhelming forces are put in to push you as fast as possible this way or that. And not reading the mind of the developers correctly the very first time Will cost you the fight.
- No save. Which makes the next problem even worse:
- The games take a Long time; a fight often takes over an hour even if you fail pretty fast, and I've yet to play one that could be completed in under 1½. This is Way Too Much Time, and feels very unnecesary.

All in all, I am sorely disappointed. There is still hope, but this one needs Major fixes.

reviewText:
I've only played the demo of this and I have never played the board game (more of a 40k gamer) so this may render my comments invalid but just in case....

I enjoy Warmachine. I enjoy turn based strategy and I really like the Warmachine ethos and concept. However I cannot recommend this game yet because the user interface is the

CLUNKIEST GAME INTERFACE SINCE GAMES WERE PLAYED ON STONE TABLETS!

Seriously this is almost unplayable! Whever play tested this for the developers must have had some kind of deal with a rival firm because there is no way this should have passed testing. It's not the size of the UI or the fact that the units move on a square grid (these are pretty much the same as XCOM and that gameplay is excellent) it's just the fact that it will often not register what the player is doing. Trying to change the facing of your units is best guess because often the arrow pointer just wont follow the mouse direction so you just press excecute hoping that the 25% chance you have of getting the orientation you want will come out. Also whilst the units move on a grid the curser option does not and so it is often pot luck which of the available squares your unit will move to. This could all be fixed witha  decent patch but it needs to happen before the game can be played.

On another topic buildings block the camera and so unless you are playing on an empty map you can't get the camera into a position where you can accurately see what is going on. The entire second campaign mission is played through narrow streets and no matter where you place the camera it is trying to look over a wall. This can make the UI even more infuriating as you try to wrestle with the camera to get it to look at the squares you want only to find that the UI has frozen your unit so it can only move in the opposite direction!

The other thing I noticed is that the game can be very tight lipped sometimes about which unit you should be using. If you have a unit that hasn't completed it's action you can't select the next unit even if all you can do with the previous one is end it's action but it often won't tell you which unit you should be selecting. This is likely something that will come with practice and as I said I only played the demo so maybe it is something I will get used to in time.

As I said at the beginning I did enjoy the missions I played of this and I am going to keep it in my wishlist but until they patch the UI and camera I certainly won't be spending any money on this and I suggest you don't either.

reviewText:
Update: June 2015

I honestly have been doing what I can to really be fair, and I really want to LIKE the game, but there's still so much that keeps it from being what it could be.

The changes since my original review of the game that I have seen have been incremental and marginable at best. Small details that iron out rough edges, but still leaving large flaws that run through the game.

Barring a severe overhaul of the game on every level, I still say to pick up the demo of the game and see how you feel with that, Otherwise, behave like there's still an 'Early Access' banner on the page.

----- Original Review ----

Despite what the site says, despite what the people promoting the game may say.... this game is still deserving of the term 'Early Access'... I'm hoping that maybe a glitch or error was made on the page that took that down, but I'm still sitting here and wishing that Steam might have the same 'return' policy that Origin has (yeah, that's right, I'm saying that this game makes Origin better than Steam, that's how far it's pushed me.)

If you're hard-up for a turn-based strategy game to play, there really are better ones out there. Otherwise, if you're that much a fan of the tabletop game and wanna see (some of) your favorite warcasters out there actually move and do things, go right ahead.

I'm just gonna delete this now, hopefully I can come back in a while and see a more polished product that I feel was worth my 20$

reviewText:
Want to play a game with intuitive camera systems, realistic requirements and game play that doesn't randomly screw up?  Play something else if you answered yes.

White Moon Dreams has heavily disappointed me with this title, giving a black eye to the Privateer Press IP of Warmachine.  The controls are not intuitive and allows for background items like trees to block your ability to interract with the maps.  Occasionally a click to a specific square will instead rocket your selected unit across the map somewhere else.

The part that is most frustrating was that during the time the game was being developed and kickstarted requirements, while never confirmed, were said to be within the normal performance for games of these era.  Guild Wars 2 at full effects or FFXIV: ARR, no problem on my system.  Warmachine Tactics however ends it.  Its been 7 months with only minimal improvement on the stability end.

If you have a modern gaming rig (8gb Ram, 3+ ghz quadcore processor, NVidia 900 series, etc) then by all means play the game.  I bet its great.  However the system barrier of entry leaves a sour taste in my mouth for the studio involved.

reviewText:
This game was released too early - this is the charge that most people level against this game, and they are right, I don't think anyone would really disagree. It was incomplete, buggy and not very well optimised. The majority of the negative reviews seem to focus on this.

However - I would say it has come on in leaps and bounds since then.

I backed the Kickstarter though I hadn't heard of Warmachine, let alone played the table top game, I like turn-based games and liked the sound of the theme.  When I first got access to it, all the points I touched on in my first paragraph left me frustrated, So I stopped playing it for a while, now though coming back to it, I've found it so much more enjoyable.

WhiteMoonDreams have added a ton of content and have been releasing fixes and updates on a regular basis.

The focus of the game, and subsequently the development, is on the Multiplayer which means that the Campaign is still lacking -The AI is basic and doesn't offer much of a challenge (this is slated for improvement in the future). The same can be said for Skirmish - however it's a good place to test out a list or a new tactic, albeit whihtout a sensible response from the opponent, before trying it in Multiplayer. My point here is that if you are more interested in the Campaign than the Multiplayer, you'll be disappointed.

A Multiplayer (with limited unit selection) demo has just been released - it allows play against existing players as well as other demo users. I'd suggest giving it a try.

The next feature that I am most waiting for is asynchronous play - being able to take a turn at a time when I can fit in 10 minutes without necessarily having to be online at the same time as my opponent will be great for me. By that time I also expect lots more fixes and improvements. I'll probably come back to this review at that point and give some more thoughts.

reviewText: I've never played table top Warmachine, but I hope it isn't as slow and dull, as this game. There is no good intro, no good tutorial or flow, it feels like I need to learn another language to play it. The UI is unintuitive (seems to be endemic of kickstarter games), it's hard to understand what's going on, and there is no sense of action whatsoever. Model quality is very high, but it's diminished by poor lightning, effects and animations. Perhaps it would have worked better to simply present the models in the game as actual immobile miniature figures, and keep graphics more stylized overall.\n\nI had no fun playing this game and I can't recommend it to anyone.

reviewText:
This game is a perfect example to all the smaller game companies looking to expand into the digital world of gaming as to why they SHOULDN'T.

It's just horrible in almost everyway, from glitchy graphics, horrible gameplay, almost no units and no real story line, theres not much to say. The sadest part of this whole experience is how many loyal privateer press followers actually kickstarted this game, present company included. Since I payed way more than I shouldve, well over a year ago now, I think ive received one lame pack of about 6 mercenary characters only usable in skirmish or online. Considering how many characters exist in this world and the poor choice of DLC content to date, im thoroughly convinced now that this game will NEVER be what we'd hoped for. After 3 long frustrating lvls with nothing but a couple entry lvl warjacks in single player mode and no real sign of anything cool coming later on (eg..thunderhead, stormclad, cyclones..etc) I was just completely done. A couple hrs of fighting the controls and camera more than the enemy was it for me.

Privateer Press is actually a great company and I really don't mind paying these guys 30-35bucks for a three inch high plastic warjack kit that costs probably less than a buck to produce....BUT this game here.... they really milked us dry and left us for dead with this little adventure ...and that just sucks.


...Still waiting for a playable game Apr 03

reviewText:
When Early Access began for this game in July, I'd been waiting almost a year to play it. Its features were heavily limited, it was full of bugs, and it was poorly optimised- all things you'd expect from an Early Access game.

In the following months, the developers have shown that they care about both the game and the community- almost everything has been fixed in weekly patches, features have been implemented at an impressive rate, and a huge amount of our suggestions have been taken on board. For a debut game from a new studio, I'm mightily impressed.

Warmachine: Tactics, as with the tabletop Warmachine, is about clever army construction, positioning, patience, ruthlessness, brutality and keeping your cool. A warcaster defines how his army functions, so the same list can play very differently with the change of a single unit, and there are currently around a dozen units and four warcasters for each faction, so there's a huge amount of customisation possible.

If you've ever lost an evening to a turn-based tactical game, then I can recommend this.

As for downsides? The UI could use a little work and Mac performance is a little wonky, but there's nothing gamebreaking. The learning curve is steep if you've never played Warmachine, but you'll be rewarded if you persevere.



TL; DR: Wizards with guns throw robots at each other. 9/10

reviewText:
It's pretty good. Of course, this is early access or whatever you want to call it so there are a few bugs and the game isn't polished - the AI is very unpredictable and broken, the RNG is often massively frustrating, graphics are a bit flickery and so on - but the core is pretty solid.

I play the tabletop game and I can say for sure that although this isn't a 100% rule-for-rule stat-for-stat remake of the tabletop game, it captures the spirit of it very well. A few things are different here and there and a few of the most popular units in the tabletop game are unfortunately missing (Though, with the promise of paid-for (boo!) additional units and characters later) but overall it's pretty faithful to the spirit of the actual game.

The only thing that's not faithful to the spirit of the game is the very stingy microtransaction system that's being talked about. That's much more something I'd associate with Games Workshop than Privateer Press who are usually very good about being very inclusive with what you spend money. A bit of a shame but I suppose that's the age of gaming we live in. I will say that a Microtransaction system which will include characters and units, not just cosmetic items, is not something I would have expected to see in a Crowdfunded game and is not in the spirit of crowfunding.

TL;DR - Game is good. People exploiting crowdfunding and microtransactions is not.

Still recommended because it is solid. Might be worth waiting if you don't want to play an incomplete game, of course.

reviewText:
This is a review of the demo. After playing the single player demo missions I cannot recommend it. The game is slow, has a clunky interface and has bugs which directly influence gameplay. A lot of the time nothing happens when I click on units, making me click on multiple units until one activates. I've lost units because I've not been able to do things in my own order. When a unit is activated it cannot be unactivated. This would be okay after the unit has completed an action, but why on earth are we not allowed to switch between units if they have not performed an action?
The graphics are nice, but very unoptimized. Lowering settings have virtually no effect on the frame rate. The image is very blurry, making it look like an episode of 'Days of Our Lives' *shudder*. I've seen posts about this as early as july 2014 and it has still not been fixed.
I like the Iron Kingdoms setting and the mechanics of the game, but in the end, based on the demo, I can't really recommend Warmachine: Tactics. There's a substantial amount of work to be done before it can reach it's potential.
It makes me wonder: Was it really ready to leave beta/early access?

reviewText:
As a fan of the Tabletop and a KS Backer, this review kind of pains me to write.

All the framework of a good game is there, and for the most part, actual gameplay animations run really smoothly and look amazing. A focus on smaller skirmishes as opposed to the large sclae battles seen on a tabletop has the potiential for an interesting game.

Where everything falls apart however is the UI. It is so clunky, so user-unfriendly that it borders on ridiculous. Having to fiddle with a units facing just to get it to look in the correct direction as the thing you want it to kill, and then take 3-4 clicks from there just to make your attack feels frustrating and takes absolutely forever. Movement is a chore, having to constantly rotate the camera so that you can click the exact spot you want to move to, because a small rock was blocking it from vision, and hope to god you don't misclick anything and send your unit off in the wrong direction, with no option to undo (Which can happen freuquently because...) Selecting units is a huge pain. You can of course click on their name in your army list on the side of the screen... which is hidden from view most of the time while controlling a unit, or you can click the actual unit, which is as fiddly as it gets, if you accidentally select the wrong unit, you can proceed to accidentally move it where you didn't want it to go as you try to pick the right one.

Ultimately, Warmachine: Tactics is a game that could be great, it just needs more time and polish than even devoted fans are willing to give it.

reviewText:
I love warmachine, the lore, the models, the mechanics.  This game manages to spit on all of PP's hard work and reduce a good strategy and tactics game to the shenanigan of dropping every ranged attack on a single target until it promptly dies and then repeating with the next closest enemy you can target.  Whoever decided to reduce damage while increasing unit health and completely eviscerating the warjack damage table should be hung.

UI blows chunks whenever you try to do anything remotely like clicking a button and the AI is neither artificial, nor intelligent, id est, natural stupidity.

If you're bored to death of banging your head against a wall for lack of anything better, feel free to waste your money on this game for the cheap thrill of building a walking wall of artillery.  Honestly, spend your money on the tabletop game you've already gotten into if you need more Iron Kingdoms in your life.

reviewText:
I really love the setting, art-style and fluff of the world. And I really liked the idea of transferring the tabletop faithfully into a turn-based video game.

But the game is not finished. It doesn't work. There are constant bugs, the optimization is non-existent (I get sub 10 fps despite my system clearly passing min specs), the single player content is really minimal, camera is super wonky, UI is a mess and generally everything in this game is unfinshed. This game is in early beta, but the devs are pumping out expensive DLC characters.

Don't buy.

reviewText: Fun and challenging game when playing against other players. The AI is decent enough to learn how to play and learn tactics. For the people complaining that it is not like the Miniature game. First off it is a PC version so no it is not exactly like the miniature game we all know. reviewText:
Kind of a hot mess...

I wanted to like this game - I really did!  I love the world and the models are fantastic.  Buuuuut....

The UI is crazy flawed.  Its laggy and jumpy and just a mess.  I cant figure out who is in melee combat and who isnt and whats going on most of the time,  If not for little yellow lines showing me who I could attack Id be lost.

WAY too many misses.  My troops in 4 matches are shooting at about 40% which is insane because one case in particular I was shooting at a footsoldier standing on a wall who had 3 units shooting him and I missed every f-ing time.  And dont get me wrong, I really do enjoy missing time and time again when i show to have an 87 or even 95% chance to hit.  who the hell is rolling these dice???  Funny thing is, they dont miss all that much.

I cant figure out damage..them averaging about 5-7 points per model and me...well, 1-3.

I do like the graphics and the models are great.  The movie - cut away movement/attacks are pretty solid.  i think theres a great basis for a game here - like really great, but damn if it isnt quite there yet.  Clean up the UI and BRING IN THIS MUCH PROMISED HOT SEAT MODE and Id be all over this game.  As it is now, its just a bit too frustrating...

added 1/27/15:  I will say that I am glad to see that there appear to be frequent patches and updates.  I agree with some of the other reviews that this game is unfinished.  Im hoping when all is said and done, this game is the polished piece of work it deserves to be.

added 2/2/15:  I have to say, the more I play this game the more I hate it.  Was hoping the patch fixed something -anything but alas, still the same choppy mess.

added 6/17/15:  Still not getting the updates it needs.  tried it again and after posting a miss rate of about 65%, just turned it off.  this game has been out long enough to get better.  the fact that it hasnt- but there sure are a lot of dlc's - is a sign that the developers give 2 sh!ts about the players.

added 11/23/15:  After a long hiatus, i came back when i saw there were some updated. sadly, still the same game.  Why does it feel like everything is under water??
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game had a pretty rough development phase and the release was fairly rocky as well with many disappointed supporters. I, however, was one of the people who bought the Humble Bundle so yes, I am that cheap but I am also a uni student and hence, broke 80% of the time. Now this game was a mixed bag for me. I love the steampunk aesthetic and the units look amazing, the animations are very well done (slight clipping aside), all in all, the game is visually solid.

I played this game once before I actually owned it, there was actually a big chunk of time between trying it and buying it. When I tried it, there was one thing that really get on my nerves and that was, the game ran like ♥♥♥♥. You'll be glad to know that after buying and playing it, it no longer had that problem. The game runs great.

So I've already given a few pros to the game, now I'm going to present some cons.

The first and foremost, the UI sucks. There's a lot of things on the screen at once, a lot of numbers and different sections of the UI. There's a part of the UI that tells you the stats of the currently selected unit, if I actually played the game more seriously, I would've found it useful, instead I ignored it because it was ugly along with the rest of the UI. Useful but ugly. I ended up playing a couple games vs the AI without even looking at that part of the screen so it was basically steampunk XCOM at that point.

That brings me to my next point, I played against the AI a few times after completing the tutorial. To put it simply, the AI is moronic at best. I won one game vs the red faction (whatever they're called, they had three hard-hitting mechs/warjacks), due to the fact that the enemy warcaster charged ahead of the rest of his squad and proceeded to get wrecked by my two warjacks and the rest of my squad. Anyway, it is what it is. You can exploit the imbecilic AI to learn the units in your chosen faction and learn about other factions as well. Other than that, there's no reason to play against them because they play like a human with a few extra chromosomes.

I've heard the camera does weird things sometimes, from my experience, it happens every now and then, not everytime.

Here's a major gripe that a lot of people had about the campaign/story mode. The characters' lips don't move when they're talking. While the complaints aren't necessarily wrong, they made some odd decisions which didn't help it. If the cutscenes don't show the characters' mouths actually moving, then they should've done it either the characters don't move at all so kind of like a comic book style where it's basically a picture rendered in 3D or have an actual drawing. Instead, the characters are moving about, swaying, breathing while their lips aren't moving and it looks...amateur to be honest.

Here's the real kick in the teeth with this game. It's really fun. The game itself is great, I enjoyed the time I spent with it (albeit it's not a lot but that's what happens when you have exams). Despite all the negative points I made above, the game is really good and really fun. But you will have gripes with it. It is not by any stretch a perfect game. But it's fun.

EDIT: I forgot to mention a few parts of the game.

Let's just say the keybindings are really helpful once you learn them but some keys have odd placements. It's something I overlooked because I wasn't playing very seriously and used the mouse 80% of the time but I did try to use the keybindings.

Also, the game tends to punish you for choosing the wrong unit because once you select a unit, you must give it commands because if you desselect it, the unit won't be able to move. They can shoot and fight but they can't move. It's quite bad when you select your warcaster and decided that you wanted to move the warjack instead but that's fine, if I was a little strategic, I probably wouldn't have a problem with this.

One of the things I really like about the game is that when you're telling a unit to move to a certain spot, the game tells you which units are in range. It's a nice feature that allows some tactical positioning. That isn't to say that you won't miss but you know who you can shoot.

reviewText: Me and my buddy just bought this game having heard of the tabletop but never played it and we are having an absolute ball just beating the hell out of each other whilst we discover synergies and strategies from first principals. Sure the front end and UI could be better but the core system is wonderful. Blood Bowl is the only thing I would consider similar and it has a ravenous hard-core fan based in spite of its godawful front-end and UI. If you are a fan of head-to-head turn-based squad-based skirmish games then this really is a must. My only warning is that the online community is a little problematic in that it's quite thin on the ground and most that do play know what they are doing.  So my advice is train up against your RL pals then get involved. Devs seem active and committed too.

reviewText:
I think too many people are not realizing this is an indie game from a small group of developers. And apparently some people are trying to run the game on a toaster. Tip: your toaster will not run this game. Try a computer.

Haven't suffered a single crash to desktop, did once get a freeze, but considering the state my OS is in, that's generally fine :P at least it wasn't a CtD or a blue screen.

Gameplay is fun, although some of the scenarios can be kinda brutal. I wouldn't say the AI is smart or dumb, but it's generally competent. Occasionally I saw it miss out on a prime charge opportunity but I think that's a part of the way their priorities are weighted - typically the AI will try and kill your warcaster rabidly and sometimes it can be a little less than defensive if you take advantage of that behaviour.

BGM is majestic but unobtrusive. It's appropriate without being distracting. Ingame graphics are decent, so far no animations for cutscenes, which is a shame but I can live without. I generally enjoy the voice acting, occasional incidents of nope
date: try again" but generally good and excels in some places. Not a game where I would go "THIS VA IS AMAZING" but not also one where I'd be like "CANNOT PLAY BECAUSE OF THE VA".\n\nOccasional problems with the interface. Sometimes I'll attack the wrong thing because it's tricky to line up the target
hoursPlayed: frankly. Still could use a little work. Don't seem to have had a problem with the camera as other people do. But yeah
voteText: definitely a game I can recommend for people who don't mind an indie title. I don't play for just the graphics so I'm willing to overlook them for the sake of fun

reviewText:
This is probably the most effectively done video game version of a miniature tabletop wargame I have ever seen.

Miniature tabletop wargames have grown in popularity over the years.  Miniature tabletop wargames are games in which players can assemble and paint real life, scale miniature figures representing soldiers, creatures and vehicles of war and conduct army battles with them.  The best known example of this genre is probably Warhammer 40K.  Warmachine is a rising competitor to 40K, based upon warfare set in a steampunk fantasy world.

For many people the time and cost involved provides a significant barrier to entry to the genre.  Warmachine: Tactics represents a well executed video game realization of the miniature tabletop wargame on your computer, bypassing many of these difficulties.

It will be interesting to see how this game develops as additional factions and campaigns are added in the future.  Hopefully this will also act as an effective springboard for people who want to give the real life game a try!

reviewText:
When I found out there was a warmachine video game I was syched. A cheaper alternative that I can just play whenever I want? Whats not to love?

Boy was I wrong.

I'll say right now that I only played the first demomission and I didnt even finish it. However I did watch what happened in the rest of the mission and the subsequent one after that. I'll explain why I didnt complete this later.


I'll start with the good stuff
-Gamplay seemed fine. I thought it might have been interesting and from my memory seemed pretty similair to the minitures game.
-thats basically it

Now the bad
-The framerate is awful, and I have no idea whats causing it. It literally turned my graphics from low to high and saw little change in the framerate. This, unfortunatley, killed the game for me.
-It looks so bad. Even on awesome mode It looks like an early 3d pc game. I dont mind this however,I dont feel this is right considering this was made in 2014.
-The dlc. Though not as bad as the season pass for star wars battlefront, they still went overboard. Though I can go without the dlc and 2 extra factions and units, its never a good sign when your game is less expensive than your dlc.

I do not recommend it in its current state, but with framerate improvment and maybe a graphical enhancment then I might consider buying the game.

reviewText:
Tabletop miniatures on your PC. No paint or modeling, but is that so bad? I am not an avid Warmachines player on the tabletop, but I might be after playing this game!

Pros
Great models and textures that give the game a Warmachines feel.
The campaign has difficulty. I am not just blowing through it.
AI adjust well to your movments, Not always the same everytime.
Massive potential for expansion more campaigns are allready in the works. All factions are supposed to have there own.
A decent story in the first campaign.
Missions vary from just kill everything.
Multiplayer - Tabletop from home when you can't make it to your local shop.

Cons
Camera is unpredictable during opponents movements and requires quiete a bit of adjustment on your turn.
Camera obscured many times by talll buildings and trees.
FPS issues randomly during play. Not always, but definitely noticable.
UI maybe a bit too simple. (It works)
Can be a long wait for multiplayer games
At the time of this writing leaderboard is not working.
Resource intensive

Overall this is a great game and I definitely recommend it. Just wanted people to know some issues they might run into. I am sure patches are incoming and that multiplayer will grow as more people buy the game. Have fun and enjoy!

recommended:

But its not.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

>>For everyone whining about the price: This will get you: <<
The basic game
+ An entire additional faction (Mercenaries)
+ 4 new Warjacks (Units)
+ 4 new Warcaster (Hero/Generals)
+ the opportunity to play the beta

If you don't want to pay now for stuff that will get added later on, don't buy it.
If you don't want to play this game earlier then others and help with the development, don't buy it.
If you want an already fully fleshed out game, don't buy it. It's very much beta, hold off for the release version.

This is a review of the early access version, which is a beta. I will update it depending on my time played and upon release.

Now then, the game:
Currently you have access to one single player mission and a limited multiplayer. Judging from that the game seems very promising, but still lacks a lot of polishing. The current interface is atrocious for example. Apart from that, we have a solid combat system, that's easy to understand. If you are familiar with the tabletop game that is, since there is as of yet no tutorial only a bunch of vids. But the tabletop rules seem to be translated faitfully into the game. Combos can be applied in the same way. Warjacks feel nice and stompy. Infantry give great utility.

The graphics are nice and very faithful to the originals. The sound effects are great and the animation looks nice, too.

So if you are a fan of Warmachine and don't mind paying for an early access, or just have to start playing right now, I recommend you get this game.
If you look for a tactical game, like steampunk and magitek and want to see the game grow, I recommend you get this game.
If you are looking for a fully fleshed out tactical game that will get you your money's worth immediately, I remmcomend you surf over to humbledbundle.com and pick up XCOM. Or wait until WM: Tactics is out of early access and released.

Updated: Price is now in line between € and $.

reviewText: PROCEED WITH CAUTION: This is most likely one of the worst games i have ever played from a graphical and model stand point. I play Warmachine in tabletop battle games and i must say this game feels very unfaithful to the original game. It does incorporate the same rules as the tabletop game but the A.I is flawed, a Warcaster designed to shoot stuff walked up and tried to fight my Heavy Khador warjack, safe to say i turned him into paint, for anyone not familiar with Warmachine, one of the key goals of the game is to keep your 'caster safe and secure their longevity. Furthermore the models once killed have been flying all over the place and clipping through the scenery which in truth is too busy and does not make it easy to understand the game. This game does have a few good points to it, the models are in truth very close to their resin and metal counterparts but in truth i'd take a functioning game over one that just about passes for aesthetically pleasing... I have high hopes for this game but to be selling it at anywhere near it's marked up price is ludicrous. I'd wait for ALL of the updates and the price to hit rock bottom before purchasing it.

reviewText:
As a player of the tabletop game, I really wanted to like this game.

I just tried playing through the 3rd (I think) single player mission and the controls were so frustrating, that I just gave up.  Once I got into the city a little bit, almost every time I clicked on a model to activate, the camera would jump back to another location where I couldn't see anything except the inside of a building.  Then I had to rotate the camera to look for outlines before I could move it to find my guys.  Or I would manually rotate the camera to select a model only to have it jump back somewhere else again.

On the enemies turn the camera would jump inside a building, so that I can't see what is happening to my guys either.

I think I'll go back to playing XCom.  Their interface is easily head and shoulders above this.

Maybe I'm spoiled by the other games that I play, but I'm also surprised by the poor cut scenes with models that don't even have mouths that move.

At this point, I'm sorry I spent my money on this.

reviewText:
I LOVE this game, although like many other reviews mention it does have quite a few flaws at this point. Definitely worth it if you like the tabletop game (and maybe can't get any actual tabletop games in) but it's probably a lot harder to overlook the flaws if you're not already a fan.

In any case just like with War room I expect privateer press to commit to improving the game over time and in the long term I expect this to be a much more accessible game.

TL;DR: for now just buy it if you like the tabletop game but can't actually play it.

reviewText: I really wanted this game to be good, and mostly it is. I too think it was rushed out of early access when it wasn't ready for that. However the game itself is pretty good. It made a good transition from the tabletop with some necessary changes, and it brought what i expected. There are some problems tough, but most of them are currenty beeing adressed as i read some of the patch notes and the negative reviews. It is glitchy but most of those glitches can be circumvented by re-selectingthe unit or something as simple.\nMy only real problem is that the cinematic camera is really bad. Most of the times you cant see anything becaouse of some terrain blocking the view. Its nothing that major but it would be nice if they could fix that. There are some problems with the models transitioning from one animation to another but that is barely noticable.\nOverall i think they fixed most of the real problems (except the camera thing) that was mentionaed in the bad reviews, and they work constantly on upgrading, and fixing it. After these issues it is a really good game of a really good setting, and i can recomment it to anybody who likes steampunk, warmachine or turn based startegy games.

reviewText:
I am really enjoying this game. I have just recently got into playing the table top game with a friend of mine and wanted to get this as a companion game to kind help learn some of the flow of the game.

The games can have some frustrating camera issues sometimes. It is not fixed to 90 degree rotations like in X-Com you can move the camera freely in all directions. This is really cool as you get a look at the battlefield at any point of view and can help get some killer screen shots.

Units really have some presence. When the jacks are walking about and attacking they really feel like they are giant metal constructs.

Graphics are pretty good too, I run a GTX 770 4GB and I am pretty consistent in the 50-60 FPS on ultra settings (called awesome in the game)

Also note the variety of faction units is pretty small at this stage of the game. Devs say they are trying to get all the units from the tabletop into the game when it's all said and done.

Game still has some work to be done but the developers seem like they are pretty hard at work with frequent updates and interaction with the forums.

Some of the work that needs to be done that really catches your attention is the cut scenes in between missions are not really animated at all. Characters don't move no facial expressions or anything, just still screen shots with voice overs. I found this strange because when you are in key battle scenes in game their faces are animated while these actions play out.

The rest of the animations are well done.

If you like turn based strategy games I would recommend this, even better if you are familiar with the game world.
Already good game with lots of potential as the devs keep working on it.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
People have mixed feelings about this game, understandable. It is buggy, glitchy and some of the systems are downright broken, but does that mean a game as fresh as this should be hated so badly? I sure as hell shouldn't think so. Brand new and green as grass, Warmachine: Tactics is a great RTS game, a turn based strategy set in the wonderful steampunk universe of the Iron Kingdoms, in particular detail, the amazing boardgame WARMACHINE. Whitemoon Dreams have evidently researched their stuff, or they've got a couple of players in their dev team; cos the attention to detail in the characters, scenery and system is fantastic.

Warmachine: Tactics has you play as one of the 4 main factions
- The imperial Khador
- The nation of Cygnar
- The divine Protectorate of Menoth
- And the nightmare empire of Cryx
Each with their own skills, attributes and tactics. WT has you re-live the game in digital form unlike any FPS could ever do. Gameplay-wise, it is fun, being turn based, you really need to think about placement and formation. No take-backs and you can easily be steamrolled by simply facing the wrong direction. This promoted challenge makes every game fun, and makes you feel like a boss once you've rick-rolled your opponent. The game brings to life all the aspects of the boardgame; hardass infantry, magically skilled warcaster and most importantly, the 12ft tall, steam-driven (soul-driven if its Cryx) and EXTREMELY p*ssed off mechs we lovingly call warjacks.

You create your own loadouts, out of any of the factions, assign it a controlling warcaster, then load it with whatever you want. Want loads of fast infantry? Go speedy! Want slow, but heavy dudes? It'll take weeks to advacne, but the effects will be so worth it. And if you want a list featuring only warjacks? That's the way to go; paint the map with scrap. The game has a great and simple interface system, allowing you to choose movement and combat actions and special abilities (if they have any). Warjacks even have power attacks from the board game too! That means you can push, slam, headbutt and even throw whichever target your warjack is in combat with and doesn't particularly like (which should be every one of the sorry b*stards). Graphics are unreal, I mayself play them on a lower setting so my PC can cope, but it can still run at 25-30fps. being a TB RTS, its kinds your saving grace, if it was like DoWII, you should have bought a new PC before getting this, but wither way, WT uses the Unreal 4 engine, making the game beautiful on my brother's PC.

The campaign is...meh. But then again, I haven't seen much of it, so I'll correct myself, its started off meh. Multiplayer is great and fun, and every player is known to be extremely friendly. Speaking of ciommunity, Whitemoon is literally commiting EVERYTHING to this game, meaning weekly patches, confirmed DLC units and armies even months before their release, and hundreds of FAQs answered and bugs treated per day. This game has been slandered as broken, unfinished and a misfire, I consider it more of a developing project, that will in time be absolutely outstanding. I myself have had no problems, so I can count myself lucky, but to all those Tacticians out there, just hold on, the game you deserve will be done soon.

Being a Warmachine player on the tabletop, along with my brothers, this game was an absolute steal. Even if you aren't a fan of Warmachine,. but have a love for tough, satisfying turn-based action, then this is for you, this is no-holds barred brutality! This is adrenaline injected metal-on-metal grinding hopped on steroids!

This is WARMACHINE: Tactics, the game that kicks so much a*s they had to name it in capitals!
(so far) 7/10
voteText: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: This is my first review ever so please bare with me, I just felt like making a review because this game in early access started out as mediocre at best, but I kept my eyes on it, and now the game is a game I recommend to everyone I know, because I completed the No Man's land campaign, and played only a couple of Multiplayer matches, but even multiplayer looks extremely interesting, as this game is getting more and more stuff released from their kickstarter site, this game will only get very much so more interesting, even the skins and special rewards in this game looks both fun and well done, this game I recommend to anyone that get any enjoyment out of turnbased strategy games, or any players that likes Xcom for that matter, this game shares a few similarities with these games, but they are very much so a positive turnout, the game is extremely interesting, and I am looking forward to more content getting released, especially coop missions thats already been  announced to be released. reviewText:
It is a great proof of concept game right now, it just needs polish, a map editor, and a giant pile of more units (Also the option to have games with bigger amounts of units and so on). Controls could use to be a little tighter and its a bit buggy.

As someone who played the tabletop alot and pretty successfully (Woo, 2 Menoth coins, 2 champion coins, 1 champion league badge), it captures alot of the gameplay from the tabletop as closely as is possible with a grid system, which is nice. I couldn't rebuild my favorite army lists because pretty much only one or two units from the tabletop are available from them, but it seems like it would be easy to put in more. I just hope they don't go the route of 'every single unit is DLC'. That would make me sad, since I friggan already bought all the metal real life versions.

I dunno, maybe include a DLC code for each unit in this game when buying one of the actual table top units? That'd be pretty rad.

reviewText:
First stage review, 27.dec.14.

I've had a basic familiarisation with WM:T now. Eight hours is enough to do the tutorial, a couple of missions, and a couple of skirmishes. Initial impressions:

Pluses:
-Great IP, faithfully rendered.
-Simple, but deep
-Excellent range of units already in-game
-Graphics generally pretty good
-Game never feels like it's 'cheating' as it does in games such as XCOM: Enemy Unknown, where you can miss a 100% shot

Minuses:
-Blurry graphics
-Awful dialogue
-Hard on GPU's
-Terrible dialogue and voice acting
-Camera panning is clunky
-Dialogue and voice acting in single player campaign is utterly horrible and can't be skipped
-No in-combat save system
-Dialogue and voice acting are criminally bad, can't be skipped, and will make you want to kill yourself
-Additional units as paid-for DLC (although I'd let that slide if they'd fix the voice acting and dialogue)
-Doesn't look like you can cripple jacks by damaging components (ie a lucky shot blowing out a Jack cortex)
-Lt. Allison Jakes is possible the most annoying character ever... and I've been annoyed by the annoying orange
-Multiplayer/skirmish should have a range of points values, not everyone is looking for a 'big' game

Needs:
-Map/module/scenario/campaign editor
-Better scripting and voice acting
-Camera movement refinement
-Serious optimisation of graphics
-Better tutorial, covering things like combined ranged attacks and unit facings
-Better AI as opposed to simply 'more enemies'
-Custom warcasters who gain skills as they level up would be a work of genius
-Unit customisation/cosmetics (paint schemes, weapon shapes/sizes, slogans etc) even if pay2paint
-Multi-multiplayer (3, 4, 5+ players at a time with a turn time limit)

Overall, as a turn-based tactical (TBT) gamer, I'll give this game a 7/10, 8/10 if you're familiar with the IP and the tabletop version. It's a good game, it's just a little clunky. I have every confidence it'll get better.

I'm looking forward to the next patch.

reviewText:
To preface this review, I was a part of the Early Access and have been periodically checking in on this game since then. I also play the tabletop.

Warmachine Tactics is yet another multiplayer-centric game that wants to charge you a box price and then additional expensive DLC bundles just for new multiplayer units. The problem with this is that their multiplayer mode isn't robust at all. It's like having a dedicated online FPS with only one match size (6v6, for example), one game mode (deathmatch), and a few maps.

An expensive box price or expensive multiplayer DLC bundles. Pick one. $15-20 for faction bundles is is silly on top of a $40 box price. I might as well purchase models for my actual Warmachine army instead.

It's important to note that if you have no previous experience with Warmachine, this game is not a very helpful place to start, as almost nothing is explained and what tooltips there are, are not useful. This is doubly true in multiplayer, where only previous Warmachine experience will make sense of the squad building menus.

I really want to like this game, but they translated a lot of tabletop mechanics poorly, the controls are finnicky and punish people who don't play the tabletop, and the campaign is painful. Very little documentation in-game about what stats mean and what the various units are does not help this situation. It tries to be an 'almost Warmachine but not quite', and succeeds at being different. Different, however, is not better.

The graphics are really nice, the game just suffers from being very time-consuming in unnecessary ways. The primary draw of Warmahordes is objective-based gameplay, territory control, and good scaling of game mechanics from small skirmishes to large battles. There's only one mode (kill the enemy warcaster) in Tactics, one battle size (50 points), and only a few maps. Because all matches are 50 points, there's no such thing as a 'quick game'. All matches will typically take an hour or more to conclude, and that's a large problem for casual play.

I wanted this game to be a gateway drug to Warmachine's tabletop, but only people who already enjoy the tabletop will be very interested in playing this, or paying for DLC expansions for their favorite factions. It lacks the strategic depth and breadth that makes the wargame so interesting, and that's a shame, because with more game modes, variable match sizes, and maps balanced for objective-based play, this game could be something great.

Instead, they're developing expensive DLC faction add-ons for an anemic multiplayer experience that desperately needs more features, such as hotseat play. The ability to speed up or disable animations would also be nice, when you consider overall game length and how much of that is spent watching units take actions.

reviewText: The only negative issues I have with this game are the lack of mouth movement in the unskippable cutscenes and the fact that the AI doesn't play like a Warmachine player.  Normally, if I leave my warcaster standing around with nothing between him and the enemy warcaster, I've lost the game... but the AI isn't smart enough to go for an assassination, unfortunately.  That said, in multiplayer, the other players *are* smart enough (of course), and I think multiplayer is where the game really shines.\n\nThere have been a considerable number of patches to the game, and several partial factions added, plus several waves of additional units added.  It's going to take awhile for the game to catch up with the 10 years that Warmachine's been around in terms of variety of units, and they're likely going to need to add larger maps if they ever want to add colossals... but for a game that is trying to capture the spirit of a tabletop miniatures game on the PC platform, it does a good job.  Since I play it fairly regularly, it must be a pretty good game.

reviewText:
A turn-based strategy brought to the PC from the table top version.

As of writing. The game still has a bear bones UI at all times, from squad construction to battle. In battle selection can be finicky and seems to really fight the player.

Having said that all the mechanics work, the campaign is in.

There's not much to say, it's functional but has ugly and tricky to use menu's and UI. Sound design is almost absent...some units have speech, most don't music is repetetive.

If you're hurting for a turn based game with squad management this wll serve. But as of this writing this is a functional dissapointment...if down the line this changes so will this review.

I have only played through four skirmeshes in this game but am ready to post a review. I have to say first that i love warmachne the miniatures game and have been collecting and playing it for years. I also understand like all irl games made into video games that this was not going to be the same as the tabletop, however I did expect something close for non campaign modes. I would love to see something more of a guide or stat card set up for the game because while im playing i feel like any strategy matters little and im just clicking one guy to move then do whatever action it recommends. My W/L is 2/2 and hinestly I can't say really why i won or lost, it didnt really feel like a victory when i won and losses just felt bland i didnt feel like i had lost anything.
I dont know how much money was invested into this game by privateer or the kickstarter, as a backer id give it more time before raising the refund army. yes this game was released way to early in development and should be called an alpha but if its really worked on i believe this game could be fixed.
NOTE TO PRIVATEER!
please pull out from whitemoon and switch developers. please put more serious work into this game. i would love to see it succeed.

reviewText:
[Review based on Demo]

So I am an old strategy game player, I grew up on Final Fantasy Tactics (PS1 and on) as well as more modern ones like X-Com (new version).  Ive also played the tabletop version and the Iron Kingdoms RPG.  So how does this game stac kup?

At this point not very well.
Graphics are alright, with Warjacks looking nice and they have the feel of the clanking powerhouses they should.
However controlling things is a little frustrating, and I had several instances where units had no line of sight to units directly in front facing.  Camera issues, as mentioned in nearly every review, are a constant issue.  Game preformance chugged once in a while and I had an odd issue where once in a while when selecting units, that their movement grid did not show up, or in one case showed the movement grid of a different unit.
The cutscenes are decently voice acted....but the models are not animated, which is made obvious when the game zooms into their statue-like faces, talking without so much as lip flap.

There is potential here, but this is still early access, even if the label is gone.  For the price, even at 40% off, not worth it based on the demo.  Warhammer 40k Dawn of War or X-Com are far more polished.

Maybe after 4-6 months I will revisit this game, or if a more significant sale happens.

reviewText:
Ok so  I gave this game a real shot. I love tactics games and have no idea anything about the Warmachine universe and only found out it is a tabletop game after looking at the forums.

Plainly put, it is an unfinished game. The UI is not optimized for high resolutions, the graphics are not optimized at all and are terrible at anything lower than high settings, cutscenes are simply character models standing there with a big box of subtitles at the bottom as there are no animations, the tutorial is rushed and not much is explained other than the bare basic stats which led to several incidences where units werent functioning as I wanted them to in certain instances because I did something wrong.

This is a simple case of developers were in the middle of making it and something happened whether it be running out of money or being pushed by the higherups to release a product and just pushing it to market with the foundation but nothing else in place. It had true potential to be a good game it seems.

I do not recommend purchasing this game, and I wish I could say try it if you happen to get it with some package or whatever. However, I dont even recommend wasting your time downloading it and playing it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll keep the review part short:

Gameplay is great, this game has massive potencial, lots of planning, stratagy etc, of course there is a slight element of luck/rng with the dice, but this is to be expected...

The game is solid and im sure it's gonna be a big big hit, certainly within the group of people who enjoy this type of game, I hope they make it possible to have 2v2 matches, for some epic battles.

Game atm is 3* due to content, but gameplay is 5*, when finished full package will be 5* all the way.

Sigh.... So many people that are upset about the price.

OK let me break it down for you.

When a game that you are genuinely interested in is released at a standard price point, for example £30 both on the web or via steam, I don't see anyone whine or anything, if you want it you buy it, if you don't want it you don't buy it, simples.

Take note of the above scenario, no whining, no complaining, no problems.

Buuuuuuuuuuut.......on the other hand, the scenario below is quite different.

When a game comes along that many people like the look of, they wanna play it, they are not sure if they would buy it in future or not, but regardless they still have some interest in it. Now in this case we have a game that is in late alpha/early beta stages of development, bugs, glitches and lack of content. During this period of time the game is open to those who wish to BUY INTO the beta testing phase for a higher fee which is matching that of the initial KS backers.

On top of this the deal is sweetened by the addition of extra content after the final release.

Now it must be made clear that the second option/scenario is INTENDED for one of 2 possible groups of individuals:

1) Die hard warmachine fans who simply cannot possibly stand the time of waiting and cost is no object to them in the face of not being able to play their treasured game franchise.

or

2) Those who do have some interest in the game, possibly not as much as a die hard fan, but nonetheless they are interested, however they have a very strong interest in shapeing the games continued development, learn more about the game, help find bugs and generally be part of the ongiong development process and are happy to pay the increased initial price of entry.

Now when we look at those complaining about the price point of this game, they clearly are either trolls, or people who should be waiting for the game to be released at the standard £30 price point and at that point either choose to purchase or back out and play something else.

However they are not.

It is clear to to us all then, that those who are whining (trolls/patient release purchasers) are simply making all of these whine posts because they are butthurt, they want the game NOW, but are not interested enough to pay the premium price, and hence they whine because they have to live with the fact they have to wait.

What can we take away from all of this?

Well apparently quite a few people have some growing up to do, simples.

reviewText: Half-baked at best. I'd try back in a few months maybe, or wait for a demo. The game itself might be fun save for the performance issues, UI, camera and controls. But truthfully even then it feels cumbersome and monotonous. Moving my soldiers felt like a chore - and I was happy in later rounds when a lot of them had died off.\n\nI think they tried a little too hard to stay a tabletop game, and the result is a game that plays 2-3x slower than it should. (And that game is still months away from being a releasable product IMO).

reviewText:
Overall impression: released a little early, worked on and improved, currently good.

When I found the first trailers and teasers for this game, I was very eager to play it. Having been playing Warmachine for years, it looked like a good adapatation using the rich and detailed setting. As an advance graphically on previous games I've played, I did purchase some hardware upgrades, which had been overdue anyway.

I'm afraid I did not back the kickstarter, as it really didn't look like I was needed. Nonetheless, I kept an eye on the development logs and awaited it coming into open beta. I purchased it when the price dropped from the deluxe £60 to the standard £20, as I really didn't need or want the extra shinies offered.

What I got in beta was a game that was very much in beta. The multi-player game worked with a few bugs, but it did seem to roll along.  There was a certain scarcity of players, as several backers I'd talked to offline said they'd be waiting for it to be finished, while others were scared off by reviewers with higher standards than myself.

I played the multiplayer games on and off for months, reporting the occasional bugs and making new friends. When the first (of four?) single-player campaigns came out I was pleased, although the decision to then declare the game released was a little surprising. There were still a few bugs, which cropped up as I played through the campaign. Given the lack of an in-level save function (and a new baby at home) my progress was slow, but I encountered 3 crash-causing bugs in 20 missions, the first two of which were down to performance issues on my PC, and the last was swiftly fixed by a patch. For a game still in development, I am happy with this ratio.

After many hours of play, and reading the forums for this game, I think that White Moon Dreams has built this as a labour of love. It was a little premature onto beta, and again onto release, but it's now running smoothly, and WMD continue to work on it, add features, and interact with their players.

If you'd asked me when I puchased this game, I'd have said wait a few months". A few months later
date: and I would reccomend this as an interesting and characterful game
recommended: with a lot of playability. For the standard price
hoursPlayed: I have already got my money's worth (in hours of entertainment) from this game and look forwards to the extra (and free) campaigns to come. The multiplayer side of things is also getting new content
voteText: bigger maps
helpfulPercent: etc
votesHelpful:
for those who focus on that.

I look forwards to seeing where this game goes next!

"
