reviewText:
I watched the steady stream of negativity that seems to follow this game. I've been an intermediate players of warmachine, and really love the world/theme that the Iron Kingdoms titles have to offer. When the game came on sale, I decided to give it a try (despite the enless pages of negative reviews). I gave myself two days to try the game before writing the review. I really wanted to see how the game took me, and not just offer my initial feelings. So... the pros.

Pro's:
-(Gameplay) The game is a great computer adaptation to the warmachine franchise. It gives you a real sense of strategy and tactical requirement to play.
-(Gameplay) The units are very well modeled and armed after the tabletop. This allows a player who is familiar with the game world to get an immediate feel for how the units are supposed to play.
-(Gameplay) Above all else, once you learn the UI, this game is FUN. That's right, FUN to play. This isn't a CoD style action game, but more a kin to UFO style combat. Your decisions and dice rolls will have immediate consequences in your battles.
-(Campaign) The landscapes of the game are fantastic. It's crowded and but believably built.
-(Campaign) The characters of the campaign are diverse, offering a variety of witty, funny, and serious moments to the game.
-(Multiplayer) I really wish the game had co-op featuers. If not for the campaign, perhaps for larger multiplayer matches.
-(Multiplayer) I played a single match between kador and cignar. The match was very pitched and until the end, we weren't sure who was going to win.  Ultimately, an assassination run by my charger clinched the victory (combined with a disruption pistol on my opponents dreadnaught).
-(Multiplayer) The range of units and unit synergy are fantastic. And they keep releasing new units, which will further change the dynamics of the matches. From disruption bolts, head-butts, and stunning lightning bolts, there's seemingly dozens of combinations to change a dire situation into a chance!

Cons-
O.K... There are a lot of cons. As I'm sure you've all read. But the one things that I'd like to point out. These Cons can be FIXED. This game feels EARLY, like a beta. Hopefully, the developers will continue to smooth out the engine.

-(Gameplay) I really wish that you could CHOOSE the upgrades your units/warcasters get at the end of the mission. It would be a nice way of customizing the hero to your own preferences.
-(Camera) The camera is terrible. You frequently find yourself needing to change your angle and rotation to get a good view of whats going on. Sometimes, things are going on that are obscured by terrain when your opponent is moving. I found the arrow keys better for moving around the battlefield than the mouse commands
--Objects(Like buildings) can get in the way of your issueing move orders, even if you do not SEE a structure in your way. It's due to poor clipping during object creation. Measure twice, move once. You may need to change your angle before continueing your move.
--WHY does the camera rotate around beneath your god-view feet, and not rotate around where your focused? Developers, please fix this...
-(UI) The UI is also... horrible. It's takes a while to get used to, and offers little to no explaination as to why things can't happen.
--There is no seamless change from your turns movement to out of turn movement (energize or quick work).
--There is no explaination to which unit you are currently stuck" on (untill you've ended ALL it's phases/turns). There may be a slight hue to the circle below it
date: but that's not much to go on.\n--The UI takes up too much of the game screen. It may have pertinent information (it usually does)
recommended:
but it also impedes the atmosphere of the game.
-(Grapics) I realize you saved a ton of money by using still art for the cut-scenes... but really... you think it would kill you to have moving mouths and a believable conversation going on?
-(BUGS) The game is very buggy...
--Units sometimes graphically face the wrong way.
--The game will crash if you complete conversations or objectives in the wrong order (In your very first mission
hoursPlayed: I crashed my game when I ran to activate Bandit with my warcaster earlier than the game wanted me to (Since I know in game that warcasters can activate jacks). I bypassed the first conversation (about being attacked) by fleeing straight to bandit (where is bandit conversation) and when the first conversation finally happenned
voteText: it crashed the game. So please
helpfulPercent: treat this game like a story
votesHelpful: and follow the flow of the game.\n\nConclusion: I'm recommending this game. It's a diamond in the rough. Some very... rough... rough. The problems that exist in the game are superficial and can easily be learned and avoided. The core mechanics of the game are still very fun

commentsCount: wait a day or two before writing a review out of anxiety. The UI isn't impossible

reviewText:
I'm a HUGE fan of the IP - have been following Privateer Press since before the tabletop game when the setting was first introduced, so nothing but anticipation from me when Tactics was announced. I did not jump on the bandwagon during the early release because the price tag seemed a bit high for me when those early reviews weren't very favorable. Same story when the game was released.

Finally tried out the free demo. I'm very sad to confirm that everything people have said is true. The game isn't unfun - it's just an unpolished mess that wouldn't be considered finished by most standards. Lack of animated dialogue is a glaring example. Not a deal-breaker, but how can Whitemoon really expect us to pay full price for a game where so many obvious corners have been cut?

At half the price, I'd still be very hesitant to buy in because you're only getting a core list of units. We're expected to pay an addition $2-$3 per extra unit type that we want to add? Nice try - give us an entire expansion worth of units for $10, work on the animation issues, and then I might consider purchasing the game... if I can get a good sale price.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: This review is soley based on the Demo Experience, but im convinced that the problems transfer into the full product, as i read some other reviews. I purley judge the product as is, without prior knowledge of the boardgame, from which it seems to originate.

After almost 100 hours spent in XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within i was desperate for another squad oriented - turnbased strategy game, and suddenly there was WARMACHINE: Tactics.

Within the first two missions, fatal problems with the game become rather obvious, making it a real act of patiens to play the game.
The game just suddenly freezes sometimes, it seems like some animations or certain hit-FX are just badly coded and making your PC randomly freeze on certain actions. Which is odd because the game runs perfectly fine else. The motion blur is sickening, but can be disabled.
The camera is a absolute mess, on 50% of the actions it clips through walls or buildings, and it randomly jumps between your previous location and the current action of your enemy. Instead the camera should stay on the enemy, if its the enemies turn.
Hotkeys for ability seleciton and general UI seem unfinished. As an example: sometimes you can boost the attack (aka chance to hit) or the power (dmg) of a selected skill, sometimes boosting attack does both, but the UI shows a total useless power" button too
date: instead of having a third kind of button "attack + power".\nUnit selection progress is a mess
recommended: and the game doenst communicate basic rulesets to you
hoursPlayed: for example choosing combined range attacks on normal soldiers will only allow you to move and attack with normal soldiers
voteText: until the attack is finally executed. Another example would be out of turn actions. In general you are never sure in which "phase" of a turn you are in

column18: and you are often just waiting for your own units to peform

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of the Privateer Press Games, and especially Warmahordes.  However, this game was released way too early.  I have ran into multiple problems where I am not able to activate all my units.  I've also ran into issues after using spells like Energizer that it will actually end the activation of both my warcaster and my warjack without being able to use the rest of my warcasters activation and my warjacks activation (The END TURN button will be red, showing all units have been activated).\n\nIt's an interesting spin to the board game, but the functions of the game were not ready for launch.

reviewText:
Warmachine Tactics is a thrown together mess. If you plan to buy it, wait for it to be on sale. The campaign is hardly worth the effort as it is broken rather than genuinely difficult. The skirmish matches are OK, but the enemy AI leaves much to be desired. Think of this game as a multiplayer only rather than any kind of fulfilling single-player experience.

STORY:
The campaign is arduous and the difficulty mainly comes from the game being broken rather than genuinely hard. The campaign flip flops on which characters are critical to your success and nothing is more frustrating than seeing Keep Jakes
hoursPlayed: and your Warjacks alive." However
voteText: several missions throughout the game only have "Keep Jakes alive." as your main objective. It gets incredibly frustrating when you have taken the enemy units apart and their one remaining unit runs past all our others to critically strike one your five or more essential characters
helpfulPercent: causing you to instantly lose the game after you may have put an hour or more into it. Though the campaign claims to sport an "extensive
votesHelpful: story-driven experience"; I felt that it was sloppy and the story is one-dimensional and dull. Your character
votesTotal: Lt. Allison Jakes
votesFunny: proves her worth as she makes the worst tactical decisions possible and costs countless lives of her loyal men as they die for her petty revenge quest and foolish mistakes. Multiple times in the story
commentsCount: she defeats an enemy warcaster who then begs for their life causing her to stay her hand
column16: only so that they can attack her while her men stand idly by. So many of the "story moments" in the game involve Lt. Jakes forcing her men to charge into completely avoidable conflicts causing them to die in droves as she celebrates her tactical genius. I hated Jakes by end of the campaign. But worry not all you fanboys
column17:
all of the other characters will constantly yammer on and on about how amazing and brilliant she is.

PRESENTATION:
The game has nice animations and I really enjoyed the look of each unit. However
column18: glitches abound and many times the enemy characters can run straight through walls to attack you when you thought you were safe. During the enemy turn
column19: the camera bugs out like mad
column20: crudely snapping back to an overhead view of your troops before being wrestled away from you to watch an enemy character stroll towards you and snapping back into overhead again. The process can be nauseating and since you will usually be hilariously outnumbered (in the campaign)
column21: prepare to watch the sickening camera jolts for a good 3-5 minutes each enemy turn.\n\nAll who have played Warmachine know the importance of unit facing. If you haven't
column22: then basically you get a higher chance of damage by hitting units in the back; also
column23: you need to actually be facing a unit in order to attack it. Warmachine Tactics seems to think that it knows where your units should be facing better than you do; often crudely spinning your units to face a random direction after a completed movement. This forces you to micro-manage your units' facing after every single move.\n\nSometimes the textures and colors of the terrain completely blot out your unit movement graphics (the little colored halo on the ground that indicates where you want them to move to). This makes viewing countdown timers
column26: and many other essential graphical cues
column27: nearly impossible in some levels.\n\nThe game also feels the need to prevent you from pausing it
column28: ever. You can bring up a pause menu
column29:
but the game continues to run in the background. This can be very annoying even though with a turn-based game you don't need to worry about being attacked during your turn.

SUMMARY:
There is a lot more I could say about this game
column30: but in the interest of brevity I will hold off for now. Just know that for $39.99
column31: you will be getting little better than a late Alpha or early Beta stage game that is riddled with issues. Yes

column33: this game shames its table-top counterpart by being sloppy and bug infested. I do enjoy playing the Skirmishes and the multiplayer is not bad. If you really love Warmachine

reviewText: The game is definitely still a work in progress, but it's getting better when you compare it to when they brought it out. I haven't played much online, but I have had few problems with it. I like the campaign mode, and I'm eagerly waiting for them to bring out more models for all of the factions. It has its glitchy moments, and it does weird things with facing sometimes, but I'm impressed with the body of work they've put in so far, and the developers seem to be open to feedback from the public. It's not a polished work yet, but give it time, I think it will.

reviewText: The game is definitely still a work in progress, but it's getting better when you compare it to when they brought it out. I haven't played much online, but I have had few problems with it. I like the campaign mode, and I'm eagerly waiting for them to bring out more models for all of the factions. It has its glitchy moments, and it does weird things with facing sometimes, but I'm impressed with the body of work they've put in so far, and the developers seem to be open to feedback from the public. It's not a polished work yet, but give it time, I think it will.

reviewText:
At a glance this game needs a lot of interface work.

-Selecting unit can be hard for sometimes
-Your units don't face enemies or even the direction they are moving sometimes
-Facing is extremely important which they fail to mention in the tutorial
-I didn't really know how many action points i had ( Im sure it was there I just didn't know where to look)
-when rotating the camera in the demo mission there are angles which you can't see from which forces you to use a bad angles
-When fighting enemies it tells you chance to hit, crit, and range of damage but doesn't tell you the units armor rating (there are units that will take no damage if armor rating is too high... kind of important information)
- When abilites like sprint" go off you just have to know what they do and use them after activation there are alot of other abilites so I assume that you would just have to memorize them all (which would happen eventually but at a glance...)

From a mechanics perspective It has lots of good elements It would be interesting to see the rest of the game. So I might check out the table top version but if the demo is a reflection of the actual game this thing should still be in beta."

reviewText: I'll echo what others have said about this one being cumbersome. I won't mention the tiresome and lengthy un-skippable introductions or the overly complex instructions right from the start (forget about being eased into the game). Neither will I talk about the plodding speed and uninspired nature of gameplay that feels like you've seen this done elsewhere (and better). What I will mention is how this game captures the same feeling of walking into a Game's Workshop store as a complete newbie and being put off by the clerk and kids playing in the back who won't look at you twice because you don't know what colour underwear the Necrons use. It feels quite out of depth for newcomers to the universe (like me) and does nothing to gain your interest. I really wanted to give it a fair go but can't help feeling that I'm in way over my head with not a lifeline or friendly shop assistant in sight.

reviewText: Of the 30% of players who beat mission 1, only a third of them get as far as beating mission 3. It's just... kinda missing life to it I guess, the mission design as far as I've seen is nothing special, the UI is clunky and bizarrely shrunken, and the mechanics don't have many satisfying gotcha moments to them. A strategy game should stimulate you with feelings that you have done something really clever, or made a totally stupid mistake, but aside from accidentally letting your giant robot get too far away from your character, there wasn't much of those things in the short time I played it before losing interest.

reviewText: To be honest, I am shocked that this is considered a finished game.  This plays far more like a reasonably far along early access game than anything.  Graphical and sound glitches are everywhere.  Campaign cutscenes are just character models standing *completely* still while the camera pans.  The HUD is atrocious, with no clear way of cycling through troops or immediately telling which troops are still active.  The screen is constantly marked with the version number and framerate, insisting that this isn't even a 1.0 release.  The list continues.\n\nIf this game was in early access, I would quickly overlook these problems.  After all, the core game is here and it is pretty solid.  But to call this a finished product is ludicrous.  It's too bad, too.  If you are willing to look past this, the core game is worth a few dollars and a few hours of investment.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I hate to post a negative review on what should be a very interesting game -- but after 2.5 hours, I am fed up with the interface.

THE GOOD: The premise of the game is great, and the combat system (which I assume is true to the tabletop version) is refreshingly original.  I especially enjoy the ability to combine volleys of ranged attacks, as well as the dynamic of focus allocation.  The units are sufficiently diverse, and it seems to have all of the elements needed to be great.

THE BAD: The view/interface is terrible.  An ability to see the battlefield is CRUCIAL for this sort of game, but the zoom feature doesn't allow you to zoom out to a level that would be strategically useful.  You're stuck in tunnel vision.  It sounds like a small thing, I know, but it's integral to gameplay.  It'd be like if an otherwise brilliant shooter only allowed you to play in the third person.  No matter how cool the guns are, the game's a flop.

THE UGLY: A handful of annoyingly simple bugs show that not only was this game unforgivably unpolished, but its developers clearly don't care about addressing the issues.

reviewText:
As strategy games go, this game still needs a lot of work, in my opinion.  The control interface is clunky and unresponsive, it's too easy to give the wrong command to your units without any way to undo them, actually activating your units gets exponentially more tedious the more units you have under your control, the maps are difficult to read in terms of where you can and can't go, even the distances your units can move becomes impossible to determine on certain maps because of the color schemes, the minimap is almost unusable because of how little information it gives you and how difficult it is to navigate around, mission objectives are revealed to you either very obviously or way too obscurely (there is no middle ground), and for some reason shields seem to be more effective weapons than spears, swords, and guns.

All that said, it's a decent adaptation of the miniatures game, but unfortunately the mechanics slow the game down, rather than enhance it.  Smaller games are the most fun, which is really unfortunate given that they keep adding more and more options for you to use, with the end result I imagine being that one would be able to pit sizeable armies against one another.  In my experience, though, I can't even imagihe how slow and tedious activating a large-scale army would be, whether against the PC or, I shudder to imagine, against another opponent.

The game has potential, it's just not there yet... and it's already been in development for a long time now... I don't think it's worth the money in its current incarnation.  Maybe... hopefully... they can fix it and soon.

reviewText:
This Game does NOT play like the tabletop at all, DO NOT BUY IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR A REMAKE OF THE TABLETOP:
- They have removed STR and POW and replaced with DMG (same for melee and ranged)
- There is a MAG stat (I have no idea what this does, probably same as MAT or RAT for magic)
- Infantry (not solos) do not behave as units and instead play like solos (and even have health)
- There is a box grid for movement and range checks that allows for full pre-measuring
- No damage grid for Warjacks, just health
- Warcasters Level Up" apparentley
- The base stat values have been changed
date: e.g. 2 - 5 ARM base\n- There is no "dice rolling" everything is just straight up decided by a % chance
recommended:
this changes how boosting works as well as removes critical misses (rolling all ones) and perfect hits (rolling all sixes)
- Criticals have been changed and now just deal extra damage instead of applying critical effects

I'm sure that there are more problems to be discovered

reviewText:
I never played the tabletop game, and I don't know much about the setting.

I got the game because I like turn-based tactical games. Warmachine is certainly rough in several features and probably made with a quite low budget, but the mechanics are very solid. I am having fun playing the campaign. I wish there were more single player campaigns.

The Multiplayer is solid as well, but repetitive since there are just a few maps and once you know which army you like, there is tendency to keep using the same one.

Overall I like the effort and I hope the developers will continue to expand and support this very good game.

EDIT: Unfortunately I cannot support a game that is releasing micro-DLCs by the dozens with an outrageous price. Do not buy until the game will be feature-complete.

reviewText: Well, I've been playing  this game until the last mission in single player and after everything I've choose to change my recommendation. I still recommend it for the multiplayer, but I believe that is only one part of the game. The single player campaign is terrible. There isn't a difficult level option, and no option to save/load. The AI is stupid. And I have serious doubts if the percentage values of the attacks is correct. Every mission is the same thing, stupid and unclear objectives and waves of enemies. You are in a perpetual disadvantage in comparison with the machine. I'm mean, the disadvantage is unfair, is not like Xcom where the enemies begin with the better position and know the terrain, but you gain better equipment and the soldiers really develop. No, not in warmachine. Here your unities doesn't, your caster improve from the weak warcaster to the regular warcaster. Different of the Xcom, when the enemy have a fixed number of unities, here the machine just doesn't. In certain missions the number of enemies is infinite. The last mission you take damage for the enemies and from some evil machine, and not a low damage. No, is more than 50% of health of your unity! Thats stupid, thats unfair. That's atari level of design!  Even the last  mission of Warcraft 3 and Frozen Throne is not that level of difficulty. Seriously, after xcom that game is a shame!\nSo, there are better games of turn level strategy in steam. Don't buy this game only because the graphics look cool. They are, but the gameplay, eve in the multiplayer, still broken. All the attacks and magic look the same, doesn't matter if it is an electrical attack, or fire attack or ice attack or a shot or a explosion.\nSee, I really like Iron Kingdoms, a have minis, books and all, but that game just doesn't do justice to the scenario.

reviewText:
I think there is some misunderstanding about this game, this is not your typical strategy or tactical game. Warmachine Tactics is essentiantially the Tabletop game put into a videogame. I bought this game because I used to be a Warhammer tabletop player and was looking to get into tabletop games again, I heard about Warmachine and Privateer Press. What this game does is essentially introduce you to the world of Warmachine and the playable races. This is absolutey fantastic! Rather than go out and spend hundreds of dollars on models and books and hours of painting models as a new player only to learn that you didnt like the faction you picked this game is a great introductory into the rules, spells, abilities and over all combat doctrine of each race.

I see complaints about UI and all sorts of bugs, I got this game, created a unit list, and started playing quickmatch and figured it out in about 5 minutes.  The game is lacking in unit rosters but has enough variability for each race that you can build your battlegroup any way you want to play. It isnt the most emmersive or the most well-toned game but for a digital tabletop this game is fantastic considering it isnt a AAA title.

I reccomend this game to anyone interested in either the tabletop or just want to play around with a Stratego on Steroids. Remember Stratego? that game was the ♥♥♥♥.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played a few games and its quite a lot of fun. It captures most of the elements of the tabletop while still having its own unique feel. The amount of warrior health and lack of warjack systems is weird at first but you get used to it. Warriors have a nice dynamic of having useful buff/debuffs while still being fairly weak.

The beta is fairly rough, but it is coming along nicely from what i've seen. I've seen a number of community suggestions be implemented, which has improved a lot of the gameplay.

The price is high but that is out of fidelity to the kickstarters. It is also an obligated purchase of the deluxe edition which comes with the mercenary faction and Apotheosis casters and jacks. The base game with full campaign and all four full factions will likely be much cheaper. If the current price is too high, I suggest you wait.

Early Access Review

KS backer here. I'm enjoying the game immensely so far. Yes, it's a beta, yes it has bugs, but it's a very faithful representation of the ebb and flow of the tabletop game.

That said, I wouldn't advise people to jump in at $65. Wait until the beta is over and see what the final pricing structure looks like.

reviewText:
31/03/2015

I am a tabletop player, I have more than 2,000$ worth of model from Warmachine. I love the tabletop game, I was more than excited to get a PC version of the game.

What I got is a boring, ugly and alien game.

The UI is so disgustingly designed(improved a little), it hurt your eyes. They made rule changes from the tabletop game that made units and some spell completely foreign to the game, single hit point unit now are solos with lots of HP...damnit all. Warjack without system is stupid.

No one is playing (almost) except from the devs who sometime decide to play themselve. The AI doesn't nothing more than rush at you then lose.

Single player is boring, the dialog are meaningless and poorly done. With all the vast lore from Warmachine, I don't get it why they had to go with this unstructure and blant campaign story.

Avoid buying, even on sale.

Ok. So lets be honest.

There's a big ol tide of people that say 'DON'T GET THIS GAME!! RAAAAARGH' and I can understand why, they got it on early access and forgot the fact that its not finished and its a work in progress..

There's also a number of people out there that, like me, play the miniatures game.. and they don't like it because its not the computer form of the miniature game.

And there are probably the small minority of people that got it later, dont play the miniature game, but dont like something about the way it works or something..

Now while all these points are totally understandable, and in some cases, correct..

I like it.

I kept in mind its not the finished, polished end product.. that its not a direct pc copy of the miniature game and that there had to be limits to what it could do. because well.. lets face it the miniature game has an infinite number of possibilities in how its played..

The campaign is pretty cool.. I'm not a Cygnar player, I dont know loads about them.. but I'm enjoying it. It's a little clunky at times.. there are levels in white snow where your direction and movement markers are in white.. so its kinda guess the movement.. but largely the game is fun and its well thought out.. I had a go with Cryx on skirmish mode the other day and that was pretty cool too.. I'm looking forward to my first multiplayer game soon.

I would recommend this game to any one that wants a turn based steam punk ish strategy game and is happy to know that its not 100% perfect, but its close enough that it'll keep you entertained for some time.. Don't buy this if you want an exact copy of the tabletop experience, you'll never get the same from a pc game as you would looking across the table at a friend/nemesis. :)

reviewText: As someone who plays the tabletop game and tactical strategy games in general, this is aweful.  From a strategy game perspective the controls are horrid in every respect(camera, unit control, etc), fps rarely goes above 40 even on the lowest setting, randomly chugs when the computer does anything, and the story mode has no real hub or mission select that I can tell, it just starts and goes from one mission to the next with no down time.  As for its relation to the tabletop, it's complete crap.   They had an entire game system laid out for them, quite literally all they had to do was make a dice rolling program and movement controls, but no they decided to go from scratch and just borrow the name of stats rather than using the tried and balance numbers given by the game.  Units" are broken into solos that take far too much to kill and do far too much damage to a 'jack to be reasonable(the point of casters is to feel like a badass who controls mechs that can stomp people to dust

reviewText:
This is one of those games that are obviously indie in all the wrong ways - the lack of experience, budget and skill is clear in everything from the numerous bugs to the non-sensical design decisions (why make three versions of the same spell, with different cost, instead of allowing players to set it manually?) to the parts that just feel shoddy and unfinished, like the infamous camera.

I love the tabletop game and I was very excited about a computer version. Sadly, the only thing that really makes it worth playing is the single player storyline, which is decent, and the atmosphere. The game mechanics have been redone to the point where it's a completely different game system - so different that my interest in the multiplayer is quickly dying. It's not a game for WM/H gamers, it's a generic computer game based on Privateer Press IP, and it's not a very good one.

For people who aren't into the tabletop game, there is little point in buying this. I enjoy it mostly because of my love for the setting, I doubt I'd have played more than a few missions otherwise. The camera is annoying and takes a lot of work, the interface is clunky and inelegant, the game is riddled with bugs (including crash-bugs and bugs that allow both the player and the computer to do things like walking through walls), there are still minor problems that should have been gone long before launch (like the colour of various important lines and markers being too light to see on snow, or disappearing under landscape features), the default settings for sound and graphics are way off (I had to reduce the music volume to 2/10 to hear voices), you can't skip cut-scenes (adding to the irritation when you have to restart a mission - there is no option for saving during missions)... the list goes on forever.

In short, this game had a lot of potential, but it is so far away from being what it could that no amount of patching can fix it. I regret buying it at full price, and would caution others against doing the same.

reviewText:
The Iron Kingdoms are a great intellectual property to build a game from, and WARMACHINE: Tactics is a reasonably faithful interpretation of the Warmachine and Hordes ruleset. It's hard to transition a good tabletop game into a good video game, but Whitemoon Dreams and Privateer Press have managed to make it work.

What they haven't managed, unfortunately, is to make the game run. Even at minimum settings, my framerate has been absolutely awful, the action is choppy at best, and textures don't load until halfway through a given scene. The controls suffer, too, from the close resemblance to XCOM's grid-based movement, and more than once I found myself moving a unit into harm's way simply because I clicked what I thought was a safe square but was actually somewhere else.

The game is still not to release quality, and I'm heartened by the fact that WMD and PP recognize this. I'm excited to see what improvements and additions they make to this game which has so much potential.

reviewText:
i really wanted to like this game...but, its has a few major flaws to it.
1) The UI is bad, like really bad.
2) The combat mechanics are displayed in the top right hand corner of the screen for no reason, never properly explained, and are as eldrich and bewildering as Egyptian hieroglyphics to a layman player.
3) the cut scenes are static with a rather bland voice overs going over them, and whilst this has no major impact on the game play, it really just hammers home that the game feels cheap and poorly tested; and having spent as long as it did in Early Access, it should be anything but.
4) Single faction campaign, and despite the plethora of DLC units, they can only be used in skirmishes or MP matches....of which there are slim to f**k all being played.
5) the camera and its movement is badly implemented
6) it is incredibly difficult to track your units movement allocations on some of the maps

The Tactical feel of the game works very well & is enjoyable.
New units are added at a good pace, but ultimately, you cannot wonder what the game would have been like if it had been finished properly.

who knows, maybe the developer will.

reviewText: When I saw this game released I was so very excited, I love wargames but I don't have a venue nearby to play, the massive income required to keep up nor the prerequisite skills and time to paint tiny plastic men. I really enjoyed the first dawn of war game and the second was... Fine i guess, but I had really gotten into the Iron Kingdoms, so this was it, my chance to play some Warmachine. The first issue arose immediately, the price, a kickstarter game should not be so ridiculously expensive, but that was OK, I'd just wait for a steam sale like I usually do and play some of the demo while I waited. The second issue peaked it's ugly head above water while playing the demo, the gameplay was an entire city constructed primarily of klunk and the unit selection was puny, but it was only a free demo so I just (incorrectly) assumed that there was a veritable cornucopia of content just behind the locked door, what a fool I was. Even with access to the full game the unit selection was pitiful and the klunk city limits stretched into the horizon, but maybe patches will fix it, thought I, which is where the third issue burst forth from the ground like some horrible cyclopean beast, the same beast which has strangled so many potentially great titles in their cribs, I speak of course of DLC. As other reviewers have no doubt mentioned the DLC is overpriced, even with the newly announced price cut" each clocks in at $10 and while this may not be as egregious for the Mercs or Retribution bundles (it still is) the Warcaster and Jack bundles are simply ludicrous

reviewText:
I like the graphics and the animations and it does an adequate job of representing the table top game on the computer, although some of the rule changes from TT to computer feel awkward and confusing.  The real reason I cannot recommend this game is the AI.  It is absolutely atrocious in the skirmish mode, and pretty weak in the campaign.  It is a waste of time to play against the computer in skirmish mode as it constantly makes ridiculous moves that make the game a pushover.

Those of you who have played tabletop will understand what I mean with a simple example: in a recent skirmish game, the computer ran Severius (a squishy backline caster) up to be adjacent with my warcaster, who happened to be the Butcher (actually Butcher3 from the minis game minus his argii/arguses).  Didn't attack or anything else.  Just ran him up base-to-base with what may be the deadliest warcaster in the game.  Another example (and even those who haven't played tabletop will understand this): Cygnar Gunmages.  They have the word GUN" in the name of the unit.  So what do they seem to do most of the time in the game?  Charge into melee.

I've played to mission four or five in the campaign and maybe it shines there

reviewText:
Warmachines: Tactics is just what I thought it would be. A solid indie game with a lot of heart - and some awkward choices. The UI looks like it was done by the coders who have become so use to its appearance that they have just accepted it. Which is a shame because it is the game’s biggest flaw. However, once you accept it yourself the game is just what I hoped it would be.

The game creates an excellent representation of playing a table top game (TTG). I myself was not a Warmachines veteran, but I have played other TTGs. So not being able to judge the mechanics – only the experience it is very successful. Part of how this is done comes from the lack of mechanization a significant amount of what you do is left completely up to you. So if you move a character and he is facing the wrong way and you forget to adjust his direction (there is a button for this) that’s too bad. A HUD will not prompt you or attempt to fix it automatically. Do you see what I mean just like a TTG. This sort of infraction during a traditional game happens and can be exploited.

I found the best way to understand the strengths of the various factions was to use the skirmish mode. This is the heart and soul of Warmachines: Tactics after you finish the campaign and is the only repayable portion of the game. There is no option the replay the campaign under a different faction, or other campaigns for other factions. Oh well, I’m sure the developer will offer them as DLC (which is no worse than buying campaigns of physical models) but for some reason the fan boys are crying over this idea. Whatever. I like that they are offering more models, more environments etc. It means they are still involved and looking to grow the idea. Well done fellas.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not in any way a full review. Simply my early impressions with all the usual caveats. I will not be commenting on the EA price controversy here, enough has been said already.

So far, really liking it. Played the single player tutorial mission, and 3 multiplayer matches. I lost the first 2 and won the 3rd. Each battle was exciting, involved and at times very intense. The last battle, in which I was The Protectorate of Menoth and my opponent was Khador, was really a lot of fun. It took a long time to resolve, as both of us were playing smart. Victory tasted sweeter for being hard fought and hard won. When you start to understand the synergies of your units the gameplay feels very satisfying; you feel like you have to earn victory against a competent opponent. It is also easy to see that there is plenty of depth to be had here, once you start to absorb the subtlties.

There were a few minor issues, but nothing game-breaking and no crashes or disconnects. Everything looks good and works well.

Looking forward to many fun and exciting battles to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a review of the early access version. That being said, I suspect that the Steam price of $65 is highly inflated and not at all worth the price of admission from what I have experienced so far. Assuming that everything is released, even with improvements, there will invariably be comparisons made between this game and other strategy games: Starcraft II being the most likely. If I were to compare Warmachine Tactics to Starcraft II at the price point at time of release, Starcraft II wins.

The performance of this game on my PC is fairly poor. While my PC is not a high end gaming machine, it beats the low end minimum specs while failing shy of the recommended specs. I have to play at the lowest resolution (1280x720) and low graphic settings to get 18 FPS. Compared to other strategy games, where I can get 30+ FPS, I'm a little troubled. Starcraft is real-time; Warmachine is turn-based. My performance is currently halved and that's at minimum quality. The UI is cluttered, though that isn't aided by playing at the lowest resolution the game allows. Which begs the question: how can an older RTS like Starcraft II perform so much better than a modern turn-based game? Were new DX features implemented because it was new and shiny?

All in all, as a (disappointed) backer, I get the game for $20.  Had I waited for release, I would pass on this title at full price, even when completed, because there are games out there with a lower cost of entry. There are _free_ games out there that perform better than the currently available game.

That’s what we want you to experience in WARMACHINE: Tactics

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stay away from this game in its current state!!
The camera controls are bad and unit selection-by-clicking is atrocious.
The UI forces waaaay to many redundant clicks and comes across as needlessly slow. The UI is also counter-intuitive and leaves you frustrated from the very start of the mission. Just moving a unit can be an ackward affair as you struggle with tile-selection.
The first mission was very boring and ended in a stupid fight with a Warjack that had 5 armour - Needed a critical hit to damage it. It had 27 hp and I was only hitting for 1 or 2 hp, which meant I had to hit it around 45 times! To add insult to injury the game crashed upon first completion meaning I had to restart the mission.
Finally you cannot turn off the background music without turning all the sound off! That's just clowning!

If I knew it would do me any good... I would ask for a refund.

reviewText:
First: I heartily recommend this game for fans of tabletop wargaming and tactical wargames. Take note though, if you are into fast paced action this game will not be for you.

Warmachine: Tactics a a very accurate PC conversion of the tabletop wargame Warmachine. If you know and love the tabletop game, you'll love the PC version as well. Any tabletop wargamer will instanly feel at home though. The game takes place on a fairly small map where you depploy, move and fight with your Warcaster (general), Warjacks (mechs) and Infantry.  The game feels well balanced at the moment.

The single player campaign is reasonably fun but more importantly sets you up well for the multiplayer part of the game. That is where the true heart is for Warmachine, facing other players. That's also the only real downside. Since the game is turn-based you are dependant on how fast, or slow, your opponent plays. Be prepared to stare at your screen for minutes while your opponent does nothing.

On the positive side though, Warmachine is an enjoyable game. Terrain and use of skills is critical an conveys the feel of a true tabletop game. The game looks nice and runs quite well. The UI isn't very pretty but does an adequate job considering the fairly large amount of options each skill and sub-skill has. It prevents the need for cumbersome menus. It also feels pretty inituitive to me.

All in all you cannot get closer to tabletop gaming than this. The game isn't for everyone but if you enjoy this sort of thing you can't go wrong with Warmachine.

reviewText:
I enjoy the tabletop game immensely and I've been following the development of Tactics for a while now and finally decided to give it a try through the demo they have available.

The voice overs are hit-or-miss (Good for Cygnar and Cryx, awful for Khador), the UI is absolutely miserable, the camera is simplistic, and the animations can be a little wonky, but I'm enjoying the crap out of this game. While it has the polish of a half-baked Early Access title, the raw gameplay of Warmachine Tactics is downright fun, and the animations and voice acting are just good enough to enhance it. It is a fantastic adaption of the tabletop game as far as the gameplay itself goes and while I was at first turned off by the lack of polish and sloppy UI, I keep coming back to play just one more match.

I can't recommend it at full price and I'm not sure if I'll purchase it myself at its current sale of $20, but if they fix the UI and add the action cam as promised I would certainly change my mind. In the meantime I'll just wait until next year for it to go on sale at the $10 mark.

reviewText: I want to love this game. I already play Warmachine, so I was excited to be able to play an electronic version of it, so I have options when I can't play with others. But sadly, I can't recommend this right now. On the Mac version, the framerate is so low, even with lowest graphical settings, and lowest resolution, that it is unplayable. 15 fps, not even consistently is pretty bad. It freezes often, especially if you rotate the view and it clips into a terrain wall. I'm frequently waiting for it to return control to me. This is especially frustrating when it tends to lag and skip graphically, and you find the view takes off out of your control, and then your stuck waiting for it to catch up. The developer has admitted that they have not optimised as well for the Mac, and this is pretty apparent. I have a high end machine, with 20Gb of RAM in it, and have no problems running other games full screen, with all the bells and whistles turned on. I'm hugely disappointed. I just hope they will be able to fix this, hopefully not too far in the future. Don't worry about adding more features, get the basics right first please! Till then, avoid.

Basic units, Winterguard, etc, have up to 12 hit boxes which serves only to slow the game to a crawl. Two Jacks are manditory in every army. There's a cap of 16 models per army. UI is clunky, unintuitive and ugly.

This is just a bad game and a real shame because it could have easily been a great one. Perhaps if they'd adhered a little bit more to the source?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I give this recommendation with an enormous caveat: DO NOT BUY if you are expecting anything close to a complete game. The current build is barely playable, and I personally can't stomach more than one or two matches of it at a time.

That being said, I still recommend that people pick this game up if they want to support the final product. I love the tabletop game. I think that the final product will live up to my expectations when it comes to capturing the spirit of the tabletop game. That is why I paid $65 for an incomplete product: because I have faith that the final product will be worth it.

If you aren't really excited about the game being built, and want instant gratification, please save yourself a lot of pain and don't buy this game. Hell, don't buy ANY early access game. They're works in progress, and if you don't understand that when you buy then I have no sympathy for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Warmachine Tactics looks to be a potential great turn-based strategy game...if done correctly. The game is still in beta and is looking to be released in a month's time.

My gaming rig has a Intel i7 3770 @ 3.4Ghz, 16GB DDR3 1333MHz Kingston Value RAM, Gigabyte GTX660Ti 2GB, runs off a 1TB HDD 7200RPM. (I am getting a EVGA GTX780 very shortly so I'll edit for the difference in frames per second.)

Pricing: I'm not a Kickstarter Backer. When Warmachine Tactics was released on Steam for Early Access, I brought it immediately, didn't really care about the price. I had read what the game currently has for content. For a Digital Deluxe Edition, £49.99 is a decent price point for what players will be eventually getting when it's fully complete. I've paid more for other games but they were complete games, all content was there except for the future DLC with Season Passes. I didn't do any tutorials or play the Multiplayer yet, I wanted to see what the game could potential offer.

Game Performance: Moving onto the actual game itself, I pumped the settings up to max as high as they could go and played the Single-player scenario. The game was soild, running around 25-40fps @ 1920x1080 @60Hz, this is still beta and is subject to change until the release date for further optimization as well as future improvements. It played very nicely, no crashes or errors while playing the scenario. A bug with the units running through market food stands at the beginning of the level but that can be sorted out.

Visuals: The game looks very nicely crafted, the game models are very accurate to their original tabletop models and can individually pick out what warcaster or unit is. The map for the single-player scenario is beautifully created and solid representation of the Warmachine world, with the weathering effects are good so far, something you'd expect for the winter feel.

Interface: The UI is decent but large on a 1920x1080 though boarders and such aren't polished so they don't fit the role. I hope they are refined later on.

Sounds: As you'd expect, the sound effects for melee and range thus far a good. Background music is fitting.

Disclaminer. Just a reminder I've only played the Single Player scenario, that's all.

So the important question, is Warmachine Tactics worth it. Personal opinion, with the price now at £37.97 (£49.99 previous price) with the current content and now with an update (have yet to play), it feels a little more worth it but I'd rather wait till all the content for the Digital Deluxe there. So I'll say I do recommend the game but with a 'Buyer Beware' caution solely on the content to price ratio.

---- ---- ----

Side Note:
After tweeting and posting a message on Facebook. I really would like to know why the price changed since I did buy it for £49.99 from the developers and those who brought it for the higher price. Is there a possible chance of getting the difference refunded to the Steam Wallet?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is for sure a recommended game for anyone that plays either the TT games from Privateer Press or anyone that enjoys tactical games like X-Com.  While the game has bugs (this is beta after all) WhiteMoon Dream has always been very transparent about what is going on with the game.  Player issues are addressed, bugs are taken care of, and input is welcomed.  The game looks great and even with the current issue of low frames, its not choppy enough to be a deal breaker.  AI for the missions seem a little to hard scripted (very limited awareness) but we have only been give access to one mission and its the second mission of the campaign and I feel they are going easy on us.  The heart of this game is around the Multi-player mode.  Playing against real players with a diverse set of units and skills lends itself to making each MP game unique.  Replay will be very high even before all the DLC comes out in the months to years following(for those don't know the TT Warmachine has MANY MANY times the units currently planed for release).

A review for the game would not be complete without a comment or two about the current price of the game.  At $65 many people complain that its too much.  WMD has addressed its reasoning for the price and will not be changing it till after the game it out of Early Access.  The only important question left then about the price is this, is there VALUE of the game.  The short answer is Yes! How do i justify it beyond my above comments? Three little words...Collectors Edition Release".  Many of us
recommended: have and do pay far more then $65 to pre-order collectors editions that don't have half the DLC that is being offered here.  Stop trying to look at this as a pay to play Beta and start looking at it like a Collectors Edition that happens to offer Beta access.  So if you are not a Collectors Edition buy just kick back and wait till normal release or a steam sale in any case it will be money well spent."

reviewText: It seems to me like the game is trying too hard to be both faithful to the tabletop and different at the same time, so that no one is happy. I am a HUGE fan of Privateer Press and Warmachine/Hordes, but the more of this game I experience, the more I regret kickstarting it. I really wanted to love this game, but I'm just left disappointed. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let's get the obvious out of the way: I understand that this is a beta, that they have yet to go through all the optimization steps, and that games on a mac usually don't run as smoothly as on the same windows machine.

So I know not to expect this game to be perfect. Yet I am disappointed. First off it runs incredibly slowly, meaning I have to lower the settings to abysmal levels in order to play. Then many standard features are lacking (like deactivating the hot corners in full screen, or having the escape bar unselect the current selection or close the current screen BEFORE it brings up the menu) which immediately give a first impression of amateurism. And finally the options are very scarce as it isn't possible to play a standard practice game vs. the AI.

Essentially this is the beta of a beta. Showing it to the public now satisfies the cravings of hardcore Warmachine fans who do not need any convincing to begin with, disappoints those who like the universe enough to know about this game and give it a shot but aren't necessarily blindly enjoying everything the company makes, and will definitely turn off gamers who know nothing about the IP but usually enjoy this kind of game.

I should mention that I love the tabletop version and was absolutly giddy when I purchased this game, now all I want from it is my money back.

It is set on the lowest possible video setings and all my other games play just fine. There are no crash logs for this event. It crashes on the enimies turn when it switches to the next in line. I have only attempted the single player mode because I don't want to put anyone through me spending more time attempting to get the camera to look at what I need to see than actualy playing the game.

Bad on you WhiteMoon Dreams for realeasing this as ready." I can play a game that is in alpha or beta

reviewText:
Ya, this has been on my wish list for a while because I just plain thought it was over priced, especially for a game that was (at the time) early access, ESPECIALLY since it was also kickstarted apparently.

I just played the demo and I have to say that I hate interface.  I mean it seems like a really cool idea, cool mechanics, and I'd love to get into the control of a squad... but the interface had me screaming at the screen.  Like you have to use your move to turn to the target before you can attack, why isn't that just part of the attack action?  If you want to be fickle about controlling the move fine... but as long as I have the move why can't it just let me do that as one click?

And the units... okay the warcaster is cool and the warjack thing (although I found it to be useless I'm sure it's cool)... but what do I have to look forward to beyond that?  just stock troops?  Do I get a couple of these casters eventually atleast?  Maybe instead of setting up a story in the demo you could give us some of the gameplay?

Maybe I'm just too demanding or maybe I just didn't play far enough into it... Or maybe I'm just used to games that want to be video games and not just ports from a tabletop game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Beta/Early Access Review:
If you are a fan of Warmachine table top game, or looking to get into a new tactical game with elements like X-Com, then this is a great game now, and going to get better.
Current build is a feature light, but everywhere you look are the signs and evidence that it will be feature strong. The game play even as it stand in this early build is, in my opinion, a perfect mix of the spirit of the table top rules combined with the realities of video games. I am very much looking forward to watching this game get better and better.

Side notes:
The $65 is a reasonable price point. That is the price point the kick starter had that provided beta/early access. It's also the price point for the digital deluxe edition of the game which provides extra content upon release. I'm happy to pay it and play it, both help the developers make this a better game. If you dont want to pay $65 to play an unfinished game, thats fine, dont pay it.

reviewText: I have read some of the negative reviews, even from avid tabletop gamers (which I also play but just don't have the time to go to the store with a busy schedule, thats why I am going to love this more once the final version comes out).  So here is what gets me.  The negative reviews are on a game that is in developement.  If you would have read all the info you would probalby understand this.  How can paying $65 now be a bad deal?  Once the game is released in full I will be getting a lot of cool stuff to play with that others will have to pay for, get the good deal now or wait till later and don't get the cool stuff.  I say get a job and you will realize that this is not that bad of a price point, especiallyl if you play the tabletop game, I never hear anyone complaining about the price of models, how many hundreds of dollars have you spent playing the tabletop game.  Let me get to my point.  Enjoy the early access for what it is, give input that can help in developement of the final product and stop complaining and just wait for the full release completed game. rant over!\n\nThe review above was from last year when the game came out.  Then I have been waiting patiently and more patienlty and now finally the graphics on the Mac are fixed but it is still slow and buggy and it loses mouse control, freezes up and then I have to force quit.  So at this point I am giving up and will check back in 3 or 4 months.  frustrating.  maybe I will buy a PC an see if it works so I can justify giving it a thumbs up.  I wouldn't say its a complete failure but definitely not what I expected, maybe the tech company got in over their head on what they could deliver.  I would have been happier with a functional game engine versus a game that tried to change everything. Turn based like Civilization would have been better.

reviewText:
Update!
Never have I ever been so happy to come back and edit a review.  This game has gone from completely unplayable to freakin' fantastic in the space of a couple of patches.  They fixed the clunky controls and now it's nice and smooth to play.  Highly recommended for fans of tabletop games!

Haven't seen the cutscenes yet, but if they remain unchanged, I'd still give this a 4/5, I can work with crummy cutscenes if the game itself is awesome.  Looking forward to playing this with some friends online!

Original (now outdated review)
I want to be able to recommend this game, I really do.  In some ways, I really feel like it does capture the tabletop experience.  Here's the problem: even at full commercial release, it still feels like a beta, perhaps even a fairly early beta.  The UI is quite clunky, and I don't even want to talk about the problems I have sometimes trying to adjust a unit's facing.
Framerates can also be quite terrible, doesn't work at all on my Macbook, only my dedicated gaming PC.  Finally, the cutscenes" are frankly unprofessional.  Using a model of a character and having it remain static while narrative audio plays is...well
date: something not really acceptable in 2014.  Maybe in the 90s you could have done something like that
recommended: but not now.  I could tolerate the cutscene issue if everything else was superlative
hoursPlayed: but the clunky controls are really what are killing me.\n\nUltimately
voteText: playing the pc game made me want to pull my minis back out and finish painting my pikemen.  They at least got the atmosphere and the theme right.  I'm hoping I'll be able to rewrite this review in a few months for a much more finished product
helpfulPercent: but we shall see.  If it stays as is
votesHelpful: I'd say wait for a deep discount sale.  I"

reviewText:
Good looking with depths tactical turn based combat game. Customisation grants it immense potential.

I would like to point out that despite the overall disappointment towards the game by many reviewers, the patches fixed a lot of issues over time as well as adding new stuff, even though some glitches and bugs are still out there and the performance of the game isn't at its best yet.

I am therefore quite confident that in time this game will become what it should be, which is an excellent turn-based tactical game, since the devs really put the effort in it.

besides the universe is simply fantastic :)

Edit : sadly after so much time it is now very hard to find any excuse for the result. Plus most of the promised stuff is still not out and, we're in 2016, this AI design level is simply a shame to the human brain.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
From what I have played so far, I love the game. I can not wait for more.

*Updated*
When the game went to launch, the entire game stopped work and crashes on startup. I would not suggest this game. If I could get a refund from the kickstarter, I would. I would skip this game as well as all other games from this company. Their tech support is a waste of time, again skip this one.

*2nd Update*
The game runs better on windows 10 for me that it did on windows 7, which is funny to me.

I have been a fan of the tabletop version of Warmachine for many years now, this game is a tactics game with Warmachine thrown on top. That makes me sad, but I don't think I can change it. The multiplayer got old before they even went to launch. My hope had been in a solid single player game, but that was sorely lacking. The AI is a joke, and just throws waves and waves at you. I wish they would have actually ripped off some of the gameplay from the TT game. I had an extra copy of the game and could not give it away to friends.

The only reason I am still hanging around every now and then is because I can not get out to the local game stores as much as I like. This helps feed the itch every few months. Until there are major changes I would still suggest you skip this title.

reviewText:
5/10

Warmachine:Wannabe X-Hammercom?

At first I looked at the game and I thought that maybe this one has a potential, but few hours into the game I was disappointed.

-The controls are bad and they feel sticky and cluncky
-The UI feels unfinished and done in an offhand manner(Especially the ingame map doesn't tell you where you look from)
-The camera is outright fecal and needs fixing,  lots of it(Weird angles of view when you zoom in\out, camera isn't switching to a unit that does an action[like when enemies come in out of the blue or attack your units])
-The music is annoying and repetitive
-The cinematics are terrible with characters that do not move their lips when they talk and the voice acting is dull and boring
-DLC's from day one for a game that had his first PC port from tabletop? Hell, Mechwarrior didn't do these stuff until MW3(with their expansion packs).

I won this game in a giveaway with its DLC's and I wouldn't had bought this game if I knew that it has game affecting DLCs.

However, the concept of gameplay is great, the graphics are beautiful and it could've been one of those successful indie games if it had none of the issues above.

In conclusion - WhiteMoon Dreams and Privateer Press need to get their s**t together and fix this game or even give this game a whole overhaul, without trying to hand out their hands straight up for cash - because this is not how games made.

reviewText:
Beautiful graphics and unit detail. Very tough on the hardware though. Not sure if that's entirely justified.
The camera flies through buildings, which kind of ruins the immersion. But it's pretty flexible in general, although you can't control the viewing angle, which is a shame.

Clunky/vague unit control and UI. Sometimes random things happen, and for some reason I won't be able to have a unit perform an attack. And you can't switch to another unit after having browsed its actions menu, even when it hasn't performed a move/attack yet. XCOM did that better. I guess I find it bothersome having to plan all my units' actions ahead.
For some reason it's very difficult or sometimes impossible to select a friendly unit. And I still haven't figured out how to select and view info on enemy units (might be me). There are these elaborate mystic circles to indicate a selectable unit, but they're more messy than helpful.

No saves/checkpoints in the campaign. I don't mind not being able to save (i.e. cheat) during missions, but I sure mind having to replay an entire mission when I fail. Especially when there are multiple scripted events throughout a mission that change the situation in an unforeseeable way. And let's not mention all the random/endless unit spawns. Wasting literally hours of my time like this is a big con for me.

Fairly decent voice acting and story (as far as I've seen).

Yes, the missing animations in cutscenes. Guess they ran out of money. Not such a big deal when the gameplay itself is solid. However...

I can't say I'm looking forward to finishing the campaign at this point. I foresee much frustration. So this will probably be it for me. Lots of potential here, but too unpolished to risk wasting hours and hours on.

Get this (on sale) if you're a fan of tabletop games or specifically Warmachine. If you want a casual campaign experience, like me, just don't bother. I got this in a Humble Bundle, so no harm done, really.

reviewText:
So about halfway in the single player campaign and the game still don't feel finished. The animations buggy, the fps dips. At it's current shape it still should not be a fully released. (Even the patch version says 0.9).
Still it's strategy turn based games which we have few good ones to chose between. Alot of missions is hard the gamplay intresting (When the animation not convicning you you are turned the wrong way or you managed to deselect a unit thereby skipping a turn) and the mulitplayer is decent.
My recomendation for now for anyone waiting to buy it. Wait for the release patch to at least say v 1.0 and the game is on sale.

Update, So completed the Campain after giving them ample time to fix it. Gotta say it got a bit of story still not fixed yet. Bad optimization and considering the amount of effort the developer put into it it's sad. Can't reccomend it to anyone that's not really into Warmachines Tactics or have a desprete need to find a turnbased strategy game and can't take som eyesore bugs.
